questions.title: Ratio of Charges for Equilibrium of a Charged Particle
questions.questionText:
A rigid insulated wire frame in the form of a right-angled triangle ABC is set in a vertical plane as shown in the figure. 
DIAGRAM[1,200]
Two beads of equal masses \(m\) each and carrying the charges \(q_1\) and \(q_2\) are connected by a cord of length \(l\) and can slide without friction on the wires. Considering the case when the beads are stationary determine
(a) the angle \(\alpha\)
(b) the tension in the cord and
 (c)the normal reaction on the beads.
questions.solution:
(a) The forces acting on bead at P having charge \(q_1\) are
(i) Weight \(mg\) acting vertically downward
(ii) Tension \(T\) in the string along the length PQ
(iii) The electric force \(F =  rac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} rac{q_1 q_2}{l^2}\) between the beads along the length PQ
(iv) Normal reaction \(N_1\) of wire on bead.

DIAGRAM[2,200]
For bead P to be in equilibrium,
\(mg\cos60^{\circ} = (T - F)\cos\alpha \quad ...(1)\)
and \(N_1 = mg\cos30^{\circ} + (T - F)\sin\alpha \quad ...(2)\)
For bead Q to be in equilibrium,
\(mg\sin60^{\circ} = (T - F)\sin\alpha \quad ...(3)\)
and \(N_2 = mg\sin60^{\circ} + (T - F)\cos\alpha \quad ...(4)\)
Dividing (3) by (1)
\(	an60^{\circ} = 	an\alpha\)
Hence, \(\alpha = 60^{\circ}\)
(b) Hence, From (3),
\(\Rightarrow T - F = mg\)
\(\Rightarrow T = mg + F = mg +  rac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 l^2}\)
 (c) From (2) and (4), we have
\(N_1 = mg\cos30^{\circ} + (T+F)\cos60^{\circ} = \sqrt{3}mg\)
and \(N_2 = mg\sin30^{\circ} + mg\cos60^{\circ} = mg\)
questions.hint: (a) Analyze the forces acting on each bead and apply equilibrium conditions.\n(b) Use the equilibrium equations to find the tension.\n(c) Consider the forces when the string is cut and the condition for the beads to remain stationary.
methodOfSolving: (a) Draw free body diagrams for each bead. Apply equilibrium conditions in the x and y directions. These x and y directions to be chosen appropriatly
(b) Solve the equilibrium equations to find the tension in the cord.
(c) Analyze the forces after the cord is cut.  Set the net force on each bead to zero to find the condition for equilibrium.

questions.title: Motion of Charged Balls in Electric Field
questions.questionText:
Two balls of charge \(q_1\) and \(q_2\) initially have velocities of equal magnitude and same direction. After a uniform electric field has been applied for a certain time interval, the direction of the first ball changes by \(60^\circ\), and the velocity magnitude is reduced by half.  The direction of velocity of the second ball changes thereby \(90^\circ\).
DIAGRAM[1,250]
(a) Determine the magnitude of the charge to mass ratio of the second ball if it is equal to \(\alpha_1\) for the first ball.
(b) In what ratio will the velocity of the second ball change? Ignore the electrostatic interaction between the balls.
questions.solution:
(a) Let the electric field acting on each ball be given by \(\vec{E} = E_x\hat{i} + E_y\hat{j}\).
DIAGRAM[2,200]
From Impulse Momentum equation, we have Impulse = Change in momentum.
Let the final velocities of the balls be \(\vec{v}_1\) and \(\vec{v}_2\). Noting that \(v_1 = \dfrac{v}{2}\), we have
\(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1}(E_x\hat{i} + E_y\hat{j})\Delta t = m_1\left[\dfrac{v}{2}(\cos 60^\circ \hat{i} + \sin 60^\circ \hat{j}) - v\hat{i}ight]\) ...(1)
\(\dfrac{q_2}{m_2}(E_x\hat{i} + E_y\hat{j})\Delta t = m_2[v_2(\cos 90^\circ\hat{i} + \sin 90^\circ\hat{j}) - v\hat{i}]\) ...(2)
On comparing the x and y-components on both sides of equation (1), we get
\(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1} E_x \Delta t = -\dfrac{3}{4}v\)  ...(3)
\(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1} E_y \Delta t = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{4}v\)  ...(4)
Similarly, from equation (2), we get
\(\dfrac{q_2}{m_2} E_x \Delta t = -v\)  ...(5)
\(\dfrac{q_2}{m_2} E_y \Delta t = v_2\)  ...(6)
From equations (3) and (5), by dividing the equations expressing x-components, we get
\(\dfrac{\dfrac{q_1}{m_1}}{\dfrac{q_2}{m_2}} = \dfrac{3}{4}\Rightarrow \dfrac{q_2}{m_2} = \dfrac{4}{3}\dfrac{q_1}{m_1} = \dfrac{4}{3}\alpha_1\)
(b) Also \(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1} = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}v}{4v_2} = \alpha_1\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\sqrt{3}v}{4v_2} = \dfrac{3}{4}\dfrac{v}{v_2}\Rightarrow v_2 = \dfrac{v}{\sqrt{3}}\)
questions.hint: Use the impulse-momentum theorem. The impulse due to the electric field is equal to the change in momentum.  Resolve the velocities and the electric field into components. For first ball resolve the velocity \(\dfrac{\vec{v}}{2}\) vector in terms of \(\hat{i}\) and \(\hat{j}\) components, and compare it with \(\vec{v}\).
methodOfSolving: Write the impulse-momentum equations for both balls, resolving the velocities into \(x\) and \(y\) components:  \(\dfrac{q_i}{m_i}\vec{E}\Delta t = m_i(\vec{v}_i' - \vec{v}_i)\), where \(i=1,2\), \(\vec{v}_i\) is the initial velocity, and \(\vec{v}_i'\) is the final velocity.

For the first ball, \(\vec{v}_1 = v\hat{i}\) and \(\vec{v}_1' = \dfrac{v}{2}(\cos60^\circ\hat{i} + \sin60^\circ\hat{j})\).  For the second ball, \(\vec{v}_2 = v\hat{i}\) and \(\vec{v}_2' = v_2\hat{j}\).
Compare the \(x\) and \(y\) components of the impulse-momentum equation for the first ball to find \(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1}E_x\Delta t\) and \(\dfrac{q_1}{m_1}E_y\Delta t\).
Compare the \(x\) and \(y\) components for the second ball to find \(\dfrac{q_2}{m_2}E_x\Delta t\) and \(\dfrac{q_2}{m_2}E_y\Delta t\).
Divide the equations to find \(\dfrac{q_2/m_2}{q_1/m_1}\) and \(v_2\).

questions.title: Electric Force Between Two Dipoles
questions.questionText:
Electrostatic force between two dipoles of dipole moments \(p_1\) and \(p_2\) lying at a separation \(r\) (\(r \gg a\)) is
\(F =  egin{cases} \dfrac{6p_1p_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^4}, & 	ext{when dipoles are placed coaxially} \ \dfrac{3p_1p_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^4}, & 	ext{when dipoles are placed perpendicular to each other} \end{cases}\)
The above results have been derived here to give you a view of the fundamentals related to dipoles. Please keep in mind that the above results are obtained on the basis of assumption that the centres of the dipoles lie far apart from each other i.e., \(r \gg 2a\) for each one of them.
(a) Derive the expression for force \(F\) when dipoles are placed coaxially.
(b) Derive the expression for force \(F\) when dipoles are placed perpendicular to each other.
questions.solution:
(a) CASE-1: When the dipoles are placed coaxially.
DIAGRAM[1,250]
Consider two dipoles with dipole moments \(\vec{p}_1\) and \(\vec{p}_2\) (as shown) with their centers at distance \(r\) (\(r \gg 2a\)). The electric field of the dipole 1 placed on the left side exerts a net force on the dipole 2 placed to its right.
The electric field due to 1 at the centre of 2 is
\(E = \dfrac{2p_1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^3}\) (from A to B)
\(\Rightarrow dE = \dfrac{2p_1}{4\pi \epsilon_0} d(r^{-3}) = \dfrac{6p_1}{4\pi \epsilon_0 r^4} dr\) ...(1)
DIAGRAM[2,200]
C is midpoint of dipole 2 with AB = dr
Let the \(-q\) charge of dipole be placed at A and the \(+q\) charge be placed at B. So, the electric field at A (where \(-q\) lies) is
\(E_A = E + |dE|\)
(Obviously field due to dipole 1 is stronger at A in comparison to B)
and \(E_B = E - |dE|\)
As a result of this, force on \(-q\) at A is \(F_1 = qE_A\) (towards left)
and that on \(+q\) at B is \(F_2 = qE_B\) (towards right)
Net force on the dipole is \(F = F_1 - F_2\) (towards left)
\(F = q(E_A - E_B) = q[(E+|dE|) - (E-|dE|)] = 2q|dE|\)
\(\Rightarrow F = 2q \dfrac{6p_1}{4\pi \epsilon_0 r^4}dr = \dfrac{6p_1p_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0r^4}\)   [\( ecause 2q(dr) = p_2\)]
(b) CASE-2: When the dipoles are placed perpendicular to each other.
DIAGRAM[3,200]
Proceeding exactly the same way as in case-1, we get
\(F = \dfrac{3p_1 p_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^4}\)
All assumptions here are exactly the same as before, other than that the field due to dipole 1 at the centre of 2 will be
\(E = \dfrac{p_1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^3}\)DIAGRAM[4,50]
and hence we get \(F = \dfrac{3p_1p_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^4}\) as the force between the dipoles placed perpendicular to each other.
questions.hint: (a) Find the electric field \(E\) due to the first dipole at the center of the second dipole. Since the separation between the dipoles is much larger than their individual sizes, there is a slight change \(dE\) in electric field across the length of the second dipole. Then, find the net force on the second dipole due to this slightly non-uniform field.\n(b) Procedure is similar to that in part (a).
methodOfSolving: (a) The electric field \(E\) due to dipole 1 at the center of dipole 2 is \(\dfrac{2p_1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^3}\). Since the dipole separation \(r\) is not constant, find \(dE\) by differentiating \(E\) with respect to \(r\). Calculate the force on each charge of the second dipole due to the electric field, considering \(dE\). The net force is the difference between these two forces.
(b) Use the same procedure as (a), but for perpendicular dipoles, the electric field at the center of dipole 2 due to dipole 1 is \(\dfrac{p_1}{4\pi \epsilon_0 r^3}\).

questions.title: Electric Flux Through an Inclined Cylinder
questions.questionText: A cylinder of height \(H\) and radius \(R\) is placed in a uniform electric field (as shown) such that the axis of the cylinder makes an angle \(\theta\) with the vertical. Calculate the magnitude of flux through that part of the cylinder where electric field lines are entering the cylinder.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Looking at the cylinder from -x-axis, it appears as shown in the figure.
DIAGRAM[2,300]
Perpendicular component of area \(A_1 = A_1+A_2+A_3\).
Now \(A_1 = A_2\)
\(A_1 = \left(\dfrac{\pi R^2}{2}ight)\sin	heta\)
and \(A_3 = 2HR\cos	heta\)
Total perpendicular component of area is
\(A_\perp = 2\left(\dfrac{\pi R^2}{2}ight)\sin	heta + 2HR\cos	heta\)
\(A_\perp = 2RH\cos	heta + \pi R^2 \sin	heta\)
Thus, flux passing through cylinder is
\(\phi = EA_\perp = E(2RH\cos	heta + \pi R^2\sin	heta)\)
questions.hint: The flux through the cylinder is the product of the electric field and the projected area perpendicular to the field. Consider how the area of the cylinder appears when viewed along the direction of the electric field.
methodOfSolving: The flux is given by \(\phi = \vec{E} \cdot \vec{A}\), where \(\vec{A}\) is the area vector perpendicular to the surface.
When viewed from the -x direction, the projected area perpendicular to the electric field consists of two semicircular areas and a rectangular area.

The area of each semicircle is \(\dfrac{1}{2}\pi R^2\), and their projected area perpendicular to \(E\) is \(\dfrac{1}{2}\pi R^2 \sin\theta\). The total projected area due to two semicircles is then \(\pi R^2\sin\theta\).
The rectangular area is \(2RH\), and its projected area perpendicular to \(E\) is \(2RH\cos\theta\).
The total projected area \(A_\perp\) is the sum of the projected semicircular and rectangular areas.
Calculate the flux using \(\phi = EA_\perp\).

questions.title: Angle of Electric Field Line Termination
questions.questionText: Two charges \(+q_1\) and \(-q_2\) are placed at A and B respectively. A line of force emanates from \(q_1\) at an angle \(\alpha\) with the line AB. At what angle will it terminate at \(-q_2\)?\nDIAGRAM[1,240]
questions.solution:
A line can leave \(+q_1\) in a cone of apex angle \(\alpha\) and then enter \(-q_2\) in a cone of apex angle \( eta\).
So, flux due to the charge \(+q_1\) is 
\(\phi_1 = \dfrac{q_1}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos\alpha)\), and that due to the charge \(-q_2\) is 
\(\phi_2 = \dfrac{q_2}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos eta)\).
DIAGRAM[2,240]
Since, we know that only one line is leaving \(q_1\) to enter \(-q_2\). So, we can say
\(\dfrac{\phi_1}{\phi_2} = \dfrac{N_1}{N_2} = \dfrac{1}{1}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{q_1}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos\alpha) = \dfrac{q_2}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos eta)\)
\(\Rightarrow q_1\left(2\sin^2\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight) = q_2\left(2\sin^2\dfrac{ eta}{2}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \sin\dfrac{ eta}{2} = \sqrt{\dfrac{q_1}{q_2}}\sin\dfrac{\alpha}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow  eta = 2\sin^{-1}\left[\sqrt{\dfrac{q_1}{q_2}}\sin\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight]\)
questions.hint: Consider the flux through cones subtended by the field lines at each charge.  The flux emanating from \(+q_1\) must be equal to the flux terminating at \(-q_2\).
methodOfSolving: The flux through a cone of apex angle \(\theta\) due to a charge \(q\) is given by \(\phi = \dfrac{q}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos\theta)\).

The flux leaving \(+q_1\) at angle \(\alpha\) is equal to the flux entering \(-q_2\) at angle \(\beta\).  Therefore, \(\dfrac{q_1}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos\alpha) = \dfrac{q_2}{2\epsilon_0}(1-\cos\beta)\).
Use the trigonometric identity \(1-\cos\theta = 2\sin^2\left(\dfrac{\theta}{2}\right)\) and solve for \(\beta\).

questions.title: Electric Field Inside Cylindrical Cavity
questions.questionText: Inside an infinitely long circular cylinder charged uniformly with volume density \(\rho\) there is a circular cylindrical cavity. The distance between the axis of the cylinder and the axis of cavity is equal to \(\vec{a}\). Find the electric field strength \(\vec{E}\) inside the cavity. The permittivity is assumed to be equal to unity.
questions.solution:
Consider a point P in the cavity at a position vector \(\vec{r}\) from the centre of cylinder and at a position vector \(\vec{r}_1\) from the centre of cavity as shown.  DIAGRAM[1,170] 
If \(\vec{E}\) be the electric field strength at P due to the complete charge of the cylinder (inside cavity also) then we know electric field inside a uniformly charged cylinder is given as
\(\vec{E} = \dfrac{ho \vec{r}}{2\epsilon_0}\)
Similarly, if we assume that the charge is only there in the region of the cavity and hence this will also be a uniformly charged small cylinder. If \(\vec{E}_1\) be the electric field only due to the cavity charge then
\(\vec{E}_1 = \dfrac{ho\vec{r}_1}{2\epsilon_0}\)
Now the electric field due to the charged cylinder in the cavity at point P can be given as
\(\vec{E}_{net} = \vec{E}-\vec{E}_1\) (As now charge of cavity is removed)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{E}_{net} = \dfrac{ho}{2\epsilon_0}(\vec{r} - \vec{r}_1) = \dfrac{ho\vec{a}}{2\epsilon_0}\)    [\( ecause \vec{r} - \vec{r}_1 = \vec{a}\)]
questions.hint: Use the principle of superposition. The electric field inside the cavity can be found by subtracting the electric field due to a cylinder of charge density -\rho occupying the cavity from the electric field due to the larger cylinder.
methodOfSolving: The electric field inside a uniformly charged infinite cylinder of charge density \(\rho\) at a distance \(r\) from the axis is \(E = \dfrac{\rho r}{2\epsilon_0}\).  The direction is radial.

Let \(\vec{r}\) be the position vector of point P from the center of the larger cylinder, and \(\vec{r_1}\) be the position vector of P from the center of the cavity.  The vector \(\vec{a}\) points from the center of the larger cylinder to the center of the cavity.
The electric field \(\vec{E}\) at P due to the larger cylinder (as if there were no cavity) is \(\vec{E} = \dfrac{\rho\vec{r}}{2\epsilon_0}\).
The electric field \(\vec{E_1}\) at P due to a cylinder with charge density \(-\rho\) occupying the cavity would be \(\vec{E_1} = \dfrac{-\rho\vec{r_1}}{2\epsilon_0}\).
By the principle of superposition, the actual field inside the cavity is \(\vec{E}_{net} = \vec{E} - \vec{E_1} = \dfrac{\rho}{2\epsilon_0}(\vec{r} - \vec{r_1}) = \dfrac{\rho\vec{a}}{2\epsilon_0}\).

questions.title: Electrostatic Potential Energy of Equilibrium Charge System
questions.questionText: For a system of charges aligned in such a way that each individual charge is in equilibrium, prove that the electrostatic potential energy of the system is zero.
questions.solution:
Consider a system of point charges where each charge is in equilibrium due to the net electrostatic force exerted by all other charges. We will analyze the electrostatic potential energy of this system.
Imagine scaling up the system, increasing the distances between every pair of charges by a common factor k (\(k \gt 1\)). Since electrostatic force is proportional to \(1/r^2\), scaling all distances by \(k\) reduces each individual force by a factor of \(1/k^2\). Because each charge was initially in equilibrium (net force of zero), and each force acting on a charge is scaled by the same factor, the net force on each charge remains zero after scaling.
Now, let's consider the work done on the system during this scaling process. This scaling is performed by an external agent, not the electrostatic forces. As each charge is moved outwards by the external agent, the net electrostatic force on it remains zero. Since work done on a charge is the integral of the net force on it over its displacement, and the net force is consistently zero, the work done by electrostatic forces on each charge during scaling is zero. Consequently, the total work done by electrostatic forces on the entire system, observed from any inertial frame, is also zero.
Because electrostatic forces are conservative, the work done by them is equal to the negative change in potential energy: \(W = -\Delta U\). Since the work done is zero, the change in potential energy (\(\Delta U\)) during scaling is also zero. This means the potential energy of the scaled system (\(U_{final}\)) is equal to the potential energy of the original system (\(U_{initial}\)).
If we scale the system to infinity (\(k ightarrow \infty\)), the charges become infinitely separated, and their electrostatic interaction becomes zero. By definition, the electrostatic potential energy of an infinitely separated system of charges is zero (\(U_{final} = 0\)).

Since \(U_{final} = U_{initial}\) and \(U_{final} = 0\), we conclude that the initial potential energy \(U_{initial}\) must also be zero.
Therefore, for a system of charges in equilibrium, the electrostatic potential energy of the system is zero.
questions.hint: Consider scaling the system by increasing the distance between all charges by a common factor. Analyze how this scaling affects the equilibrium and the potential energy of the system. Think about the work done by electrostatic forces during this scaling.
methodOfSolving: Assume a system of charges where each charge is in equilibrium.
Consider scaling the system by increasing inter-particle distances by a factor \(k\).
Argue that equilibrium is maintained after scaling due to the inverse square law.
Show that the work done by electrostatic forces during scaling is zero because the net force on each charge remains zero.
Relate zero work done to zero change in potential energy.
Consider scaling to infinity, where potential energy is zero.  Conclude that the initial potential energy must also be zero.

questions.title: Maximum Speed of Charged Balls After String Cut
questions.questionText: Four balls, each with mass \(m\), are connected by four non-conducting strings to form a square with side \(l\), as shown in Figure. The assembly is placed on a horizontal nonconducting frictionless surface. Balls 3 and 4 each have charge \(q\), and balls 1 and 2 are uncharged. Find the speed of balls 3 and 4 after the string connecting them is cut and all four balls become colinear.\nDIAGRAM[1,140]
questions.solution:
Initially, since no external horizontal forces act on the set of four balls, the center of mass of the system stays fixed at the initial location of the center of the square. As the charged balls 4 and 3 swing out and away from each other, balls 1 and 2 move down with equal y-components of velocity.
DIAGRAM[2,150]
The maximum kinetic energy point is illustrated.
For system energy to be conserved,
\(\dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q^2}{l} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_0}\dfrac{q^2}{3l} + \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{2q^2}{3l} = 2mv^2\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \sqrt{\dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q^2}{3ml}}\)
questions.hint: The initial electrostatic potential energy of the charged balls is converted into kinetic energy when the string is cut. Use conservation of energy and consider the motion or rest of the center of mass.
methodOfSolving: The initial electrostatic potential energy is \(U_i = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q^2}{l}\).

When the string is cut, the charged balls repel each other, converting potential energy into kinetic energy.  The center of mass remains stationary. When the speed is maximum, the four balls form a straight line.

The final potential energy is \(U_f = \dfrac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_0}\dfrac{q^2}{3l}\). Each of the four balls acquires kinetic energy \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\). When the velocity becomes maximum, balls 3 and 4 are equidistant from balls 1, 2 and center of mass, respectively.
Apply conservation of energy: \(U_i = U_f + 4(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2)\).
Solve for \(v\).

questions.title: Charge Distribution on Parallel Metallic Plates
questions.questionText: Three identical metallic plates are kept parallel to one another at a separation of \(a\) and \(b\). The outer plates are connected by a thin conducting wire, and a charge \(Q\) is placed on the central plate.\nDIAGRAM[1,140]\n Find the final charges on all six faces of the plates shown.
questions.solution:
Let the charge distribution in all the six faces be as shown in figure. While distributing the charge on different faces, we have used the fact that two opposite faces have equal and opposite charges on them.
DIAGRAM[2,200]
Net charge on plates A and C is zero. Hence,
\(q_2 - q_1 + q_3 + (q_1 - Q) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow q_2 + q_3 = Q\) ...(1)
Further, A and C are at same potentials. If \(E_1\) be the field between the plates A and B and that between B and C is \(E_2\), then
\(V_A - V_B = E_2b\)
\(V_B - V_C = E_1a\)
Since \(V_A = V_C\), so \(V_A - V_B = V_C - V_B\), hence
\(E_1a = E_2b\Rightarrow \dfrac{q_1}{A\epsilon_0}a = \dfrac{(Q-q_1)}{A\epsilon_0}b\)
\(\Rightarrow q_1 = \dfrac{Qb}{a+b}\)  ...(2)  [A = Area of plates]
Electric field inside any conducting plate (say inside C) is zero. Therefore,
\(\dfrac{q_2}{2A\epsilon_0} - \dfrac{q_1}{2A\epsilon_0} + \dfrac{q_1}{2A\epsilon_0} + \dfrac{(Q-q_1)}{2A\epsilon_0} - \dfrac{q_1}{2A\epsilon_0} + \dfrac{Q}{2A\epsilon_0} - \dfrac{q_3}{2A\epsilon_0} = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow q_2 - q_3 = 0\) ...(3)
Solving equations (1), (2) and (3), we get
\(q_1 = \dfrac{Qb}{a+b}, \quad q_2 = \dfrac{Q}{2}, \quad q_3 = \dfrac{Q}{2}\)
Hence, the charges on the different faces are as follows:
Face 1: \(\qquad q_2 = \dfrac{Q}{2}\)
Face 2: \(\qquad-q_1 = -\dfrac{Qb}{a+b}\)
Face 3: \(\qquad q_1 = \dfrac{Qb}{a+b}\)
Face 4: \(\qquad Q - q_1 = \dfrac{Qa}{a+b}\)
 Face 5: \(\qquad q_1 - Q = -\dfrac{Qa}{a+b}\)
Face 6: \(\qquad q_3 = \dfrac{Q}{2}\)
questions.hint: The net charge on the outer plates is zero. Since the outer plates are connected, they are at the same potential.  The electric field inside a conductor is zero.  Use these conditions to find the charges on each face.
methodOfSolving: Let \(q_1\), \(q_2\), and \(q_3\) be the charges on the faces as shown in the diagram.  The net charge on plates A and C is zero.

Since plates A and C are connected by a wire, they are at the same potential.  Use the relationship between electric field and potential difference for parallel plates:  \(V = Ed\), where \(E\) is the electric field and \(d\) is the separation between plates.
The electric field inside a conductor is zero. Apply this condition to plate C.
Solve the resulting equations to find \(q_1\), \(q_2\), and \(q_3\).
questions.answer:
Counting sequencially from left, 
Face 1: \(\qquad q_2 = \dfrac{Q}{2}\)
Face 2: \(\qquad-q_1 = -\dfrac{Qb}{a+b}\)
Face 3: \(\qquad q_1 = \dfrac{Qb}{a+b}\)
Face 4: \(\qquad Q - q_1 = \dfrac{Qa}{a+b}\)
 Face 5: \(\qquad q_1 - Q = -\dfrac{Qa}{a+b}\)
Face 6: \(\qquad q_3 = \dfrac{Q}{2}\)

questions.title: Equilibrium Condition for Hemispherical Shells
questions.questionText: Consider a thin spherical shell of radius \(R\) having charge \(q\) distributed uniformly on it. At the center of the shell, a negative point charge \(-q_0\) is placed. The shell is cut in two identical hemispherical portions along a diametrical section yy' as shown. Due to mutual repulsion, the two hemispherical parts tend to move away from each other, but due to the attraction of \(-q_0\), they may stay in equilibrium. Find the condition of equilibrium of the hemispherical shells. Calculate the minimum value of \(q_0\) to attain this equilibrium.\nDIAGRAM[1,150]
questions.solution:
Let the outward electric pressure at every point of the spherical shell, due to its own charge \(q\), be \(P_1\). Then
\(P_1 = \dfrac{\sigma^2}{2\epsilon_0} = \dfrac{1}{2\epsilon_0}\left(\dfrac{q}{4\pi R^2}ight)^2 = \dfrac{q^2}{32\pi^2\epsilon_0 R^4}\)    [\( ecause \sigma = \dfrac{q}{4\pi R^2}\)]
Due to charge \(-q_0\), the electric field on the surface of the shell is \(E = \dfrac{q_0}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R^2}\) (radially inwards).
This electric field pulls every point of the shell in an inward direction. Let the inward pressure on the surface of the shell due to this negative point charge at the center be \(P_2\). Then
\(P_2 = \sigma E = \left(\dfrac{q}{4\pi R^2}ight)\left(\dfrac{q_0}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R^2}ight) = \dfrac{qq_0}{16\pi^2\epsilon_0 R^4}\)
For equilibrium of the hemispherical shell, or for the shells not to separate,
\(P_2 \ge P_1\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{qq_0}{16\pi^2\epsilon_0 R^4} \ge \dfrac{q^2}{32\pi^2 \epsilon_0 R^4}\)
\(\Rightarrow q_0 \ge \dfrac{q}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow q_{0_{min}} = \dfrac{q}{2}\)
questions.hint: The hemispherical shells experience outward pressure due to the charge \(q\) and inward pressure due to the charge \(-q_0\). For equilibrium, the inward pressure must be greater than or equal to the outward pressure.
methodOfSolving: The outward pressure \(P_1\) due to the charge \(q\) on the shell is given by \(P_1 = \dfrac{\sigma^2}{2\epsilon_0}\), where \(\sigma = \dfrac{q}{4\pi R^2}\) is the surface charge density.
The electric field \(E\) at the surface of the shell due to the charge \(-q_0\) at the center is \(E = \dfrac{q_0}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R^2}\) (radially inwards).
The inward pressure \(P_2\) due to this field is \(P_2 = \sigma E\).
For equilibrium, \(P_2 \ge P_1\).  Substitute the expressions for \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) and solve for the minimum value of \(q_0\).

questions.title: Work Done to Increase Shell Radius
questions.questionText: Figure shows a shell of radius \(R\) having charge \(q_1\) uniformly distributed over it. \nDIAGRAM[1,100]\nA point charge \(q\) is placed at the centre of the shell. Find the work required to increase the radius of the shell from \(R\) to \(R_1\) (\(R_1 > R\)).
questions.solution:
Work done = Decrease in Potential Energy
\(\Rightarrow 	ext{Work} = U_i - U_f\)

DIAGRAM[2,150]

Now \(U_i = (	ext{SE})_q + (	ext{SE})_{q_1} + (	ext{IE})\)
\(\Rightarrow U_i = (	ext{SE})_q + \dfrac{q_1^2}{8\pi \epsilon_0 R} + \dfrac{q_1q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}\)
and \(U_f = (	ext{SE})_q + \dfrac{q_1^2}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R_1} + \dfrac{q_1 q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R_1}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	ext{Work done} = U_i - U_f\)
\(W = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left(\dfrac{q_1^2}{2R} + \dfrac{q_1q}{R} - \dfrac{q_1^2}{2R_1} - \dfrac{q_1q}{R_1}ight)\)
questions.hint: The work done is equal to the decrease in potential energy. Calculate the initial and final potential energies of the system, considering the self-energy of the shell and the interaction energy between the shell and the point charge. In other words, change in self energy of shell and change in interaction energy of \(q\) and \(q_1\).
methodOfSolving: The initial potential energy \(U_i\) is the sum of the shell's self-energy (SE) and the interaction energy (IE) between the shell and the point charge.  The self energy of shell \((\text{SE})_{q_1}\) is given by \(\dfrac{q_1^2}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R}\) and the interaction energy \(q\) and \(q_1\) is \(\dfrac{qq_1}{4\pi \epsilon_0 R}\).
The final potential energy \(U_f\) is calculated similarly, using \(R_1\) instead of \(R\).
The work done is \(W = U_i - U_f\).

questions.title: Radius of Equipotential Sphere Enclosing Dipole
questions.questionText: A point electric dipole with a moment \(\vec{p}\) is placed in an external uniform electric field whose strength equals \(\vec{E_0}\), with \(\vec{p}\) parallel to \(\vec{E_0}\). In this case, one of the equipotential surfaces enclosing the dipole forms a sphere. Find the radius of this sphere.
questions.solution:
The electric field due to a dipole is given by
\(E = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \dfrac{p}{R^3} \sqrt{1+3\cos^2	heta}\)
and its direction with the radius vector \(\vec{r}\) is given by \(	an\alpha = \dfrac{1}{2}	an	heta\), so that \(E_r\) and \(E_	heta\) are the radial and transverse component of electric field due to the dipole and \(E_0\sin	heta\) and \(E_0\cos	heta\) are two rectangular components of external field \(E_0\). Since, at equipotential surface, there is no tangential components of electric field. So \(E_0\sin	heta\) must be equal and opposite to \(E_	heta=E\sin\alpha\).
DIAGRAM[1,200]
Hence, \(E_0\sin	heta = E\sin\alpha\)
\(\Rightarrow E_0 = \dfrac{E\sin\alpha}{\sin	heta} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \dfrac{p}{R^3} \dfrac{\sqrt{1+3\cos^2	heta}}{\sin	heta} 	imes \dfrac{\sin	heta}{\sqrt{1+3\cos^2	heta}}	imes\dfrac{1}{\sin	heta} 	imes \dfrac{x}{1}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R^3}p=E_0 \Rightarrow 4\pi \epsilon_0 R^3 E_0 = p\)
\(R = \sqrt[3]{\dfrac{p}{4\pi\epsilon_0 E_0}}\)
questions.hint: The electric field due to the dipole and the external field combine to create an equipotential surface.  On an equipotential surface, the tangential component of the electric field is zero. The electric field due to the dipole has a radial component and a transverse component. At some value of theta both adds to get the resultant field. Note that equipotential surfaces are always perpendicular to the field lines, so tangential components are zero.
methodOfSolving: The electric field due to the dipole is \(E = \dfrac{1}{4\pi \epsilon_0}\dfrac{p}{R^3}\sqrt{1+3\cos^2\theta}\).  Its direction makes an angle \(\alpha\) with the radial direction, given by \(\tan\alpha = \dfrac{1}{2}\tan\theta\).
The external field \(E_0\) is parallel to the dipole moment \(p\). Resolve \(E\) and \(E_0\) into radial and tangential components.
On the equipotential surface, the tangential component of the net electric field is zero.  Therefore, \(E_0\sin\theta = E\sin\alpha\).
Substitute the expressions for \(E\) and \(\sin\alpha\) (from \(\tan\alpha\)) and solve for \(R\).

questions.title: Force to Hold Cut Sphere Together
questions.questionText: Consider a metal sphere of radius \(R\) that is cut in two along a plane whose minimum distance from the sphere's centre is \(h\). The sphere is uniformly charged by a total electric charge \(Q\). Find the force necessary to hold the two parts of the sphere together.\nDIAGRAM[1,150]
questions.solution:
At the surface of the charged sphere, whether it consists of a single piece or two pieces close together, the electric field strength from Gauss's law is
\(E = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{Q}{R^2}\).
The electric charge per unit surface area is \(\sigma = \dfrac{Q}{4\pi R^2}\).
This electric field exerts a force \(\Delta F = \dfrac{1}{2}\sigma E \Delta Q\) on the charge \(\Delta Q = \sigma \Delta A\) which resides on a surface of area \(\Delta A\), as illustrated in figure. The reason for the factor of \(\dfrac{1}{2}\) is that the electric field strength is \(E\) at the outer surface of the sphere is zero inside and hence its average value comes out to be \(\dfrac{E}{2}\).
The force per unit area exerted by the charges on the pieces of the sphere is therefore
\(\dfrac{\Delta F}{\Delta A} = \dfrac{Q^2}{32\pi\epsilon_0 R^4} = p\)
The required force can be considered to be analogous to the force with which two pieces of the sphere and this force is also the product of \(p\) and the cross-sectional area of the intersection plane and sphere.
DIAGRAM[2,150]
So, \(F = p a = p(\pi x^2)\)
\(\Rightarrow F = p \pi(R^2-h^2) = \dfrac{Q^2}{32\pi \epsilon_0 R^4}(R^2 - h^2)\)
questions.hint: The force required to hold the two parts of the sphere together is equal to the electrostatic repulsion between them. This force can be calculated using the concept of electric pressure.  The force per unit area exerted by the charges on the sphere. Multiply this pressure with area of circle to get the force. Area of the circle is \(\pi x^2\), which is given to be \(R^2-h^2\).
methodOfSolving: The electric field at the surface of a uniformly charged sphere is \(E = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{Q}{R^2}\). The surface charge density is \(\sigma = \dfrac{Q}{4\pi R^2}\).

The electric field exerts a force \(\Delta F = \dfrac{1}{2} \sigma E \Delta A\) on a small area \(\Delta A\).  The factor of 1/2 comes because the field is zero inside the sphere and E outside, so the average is E/2.
The pressure \(p\) is \(p = \dfrac{\Delta F}{\Delta A} = \dfrac{1}{2}\sigma E = \dfrac{Q^2}{32\pi\epsilon_0 R^4}\).
The force required to hold the sphere together is the product of this pressure and the cross-sectional area: \(F = pa = p\pi(R^2-h^2)\).

questions.title: Potential Difference between Concentric Shells
questions.questionText: Two concentric shells of radii \(R\) and \(2R\) are shown in figure. Initially a charge \(q\) is imparted to the inner shell. Now key \(K_1\) is closed and opened and then key \(K_2\) is closed and opened. After the keys \(K_1\) and \(K_2\) are alternately closed \(n\) times each, find the potential difference between the shells. Note that finally the key \(K_2\) remains closed.\nDIAGRAM[1,150]\n
questions.solution:
When \(K_1\) is closed first time, outer sphere is earthed and the potential on it becomes zero. Let the charge on it be \(q_1\).
\(V_i = \) Potential due to charge on inner sphere and that due to charge on outer sphere
\(V_i = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left[\dfrac{q}{2R} + \dfrac{q_1}{2R}ight] = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow q_1 = -q\)
When \(K_2\) is closed first time, the potential \(V_2\) on inner sphere becomes zero as it is earthed. Let the new charge on inner sphere be \(q_2\).
\(0 = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q_2}{R} + \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{(-q)}{2R}\)
\(\Rightarrow q_2 = \dfrac{q}{2}\)
Now when \(K_1\) will be closed second time, charge on outer sphere will be \(-q_2\), i.e., \(\dfrac{-q}{2}\).
After one event involving closure and opening of \(K_1\) and \(K_2\), charge is reduced to half its initial value.
Similarly, when \(K_1\) will be closed \(n^{th}\) time, charge on outer sphere will be \(\dfrac{-q}{2^{n-1}}\)
After closing of \(K_2\) \(n^{th}\) time, charge on inner shell will be reduced to half the previous value.
Be negative of half the charge on outer shell, i.e., \(\left(+\dfrac{q}{2^n}ight)\) and potential on it will be zero.
For potential of outer shell,
\(V_0 = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\dfrac{\dfrac{q}{2^n}}{2R}ight) + \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\dfrac{\dfrac{-q}{2^{n-1}}}{2R}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow V_0 = \dfrac{-q(-1+2)}{4\pi\epsilon_0 \cdot 2^{n+1}R} = \dfrac{-q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 \cdot 2^{n+1}R}\)
Potential difference \(= V_0 - V_i = \dfrac{-q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 2^{n+1}R} - 0\)
\(\Rightarrow V_0 - V_i = \dfrac{-q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 2^{n+1}R}\)
questions.hint: Consider the potential on the outer sphere when \(K_1\) is closed and then the potential on the inner sphere when \(K_2\) is closed.  Think about how the charges redistribute in each step.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the charge induced on the outer shell when \(K_1\) is closed.
Calculate the charge on the inner shell after \(K_2\) is closed.
Determine the pattern of charge distribution after \(n\) cycles.
Calculate the potential on the outer shell and inner shell after \(n\) cycles.
Find the potential difference between the shells.

questions.title: Capacitance of Two Conducting Spherical Shells
questions.questionText:
In case of two conducting spherical shells having radii \(a\) and \(b (b > a)\) calculate the capacity of the system if
(a) shells are concentric and inner is given a charge while outer earthed
(b) shells are concentric and the outer is given a charge while the inner is earthed
(c) shells carry equal and opposite charges and are separated by a distance \(d\). Can you try to solve this part, using the concept of self energy and interaction energy?
questions.solution:
(a) Since the outer sphere is earthed hence, its potential will be zero, i.e., \(V_B = 0\). If \(q'\) is the charge induced on shell B, then
\(\dfrac{q + q'}{4\pi\epsilon_0 b} = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow q' = -q\)

DIAGRAM[1,150]

So electric field at a point P between the shells is
\(E = E_A + E_B = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q}{r^2}\) [as \(E_B = E_{in} = 0\)]
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{-dV}{dr} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{q}{r^2}\) [as \(E = -\dfrac{dV}{dr}\)]
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_V^0 dV = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\displaystyle\int_a^b \dfrac{dr}{r^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left(\dfrac{1}{a} - \dfrac{1}{b}ight)\)
Since, \(C = \dfrac{q}{V}\)
\(\Rightarrow C = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0 ab}{b - a} \quad ...(1)\)
From this it is clear that
(i) As \(b 	o \infty\) equation (1) reduces to \(C 	o 4\pi\epsilon_0 a\).
So, we can say that, a spherical conductor is a spherical capacitor with its other plate of infinite radius.
(ii) As \(a\) and \(b\) both become very large such that \(b - a\) has a finite and small value, say \(d\), then \(4\pi ab = 4\pi a^2 = 4\pi\dfrac{A}{d}\) \(= A\) and so equation (1) reduces to \(C = \dfrac{\epsilon_0 A}{d}\) and hence we observe that a spherical capacitor behaves as a parallel plate capacitor when its spherical surfaces have large radii and are close to each other.
(b) In this situation \(V_A = 0\) so if \(q'\) is the charge induced on shell A, then
\(\dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left(\dfrac{q'}{a} + \dfrac{q}{b}ight) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow q' = -\dfrac{a}{b}q\)
Since no field will exist at P due to B as P lies inside the shells, so the field at a point P, between the conductor is
\(E = E_A + E_B = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \dfrac{q'}{r^2}\)

DIAGRAM[2,120]

\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dV}{dr} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left(-\dfrac{a}{b}\dfrac{q}{r^2}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow C_1 = \dfrac{b}{a}C (< C)\) [as \(b > a\)] ...(2)
Also, we note that in this situation \(q_B\) is not equal to \(-q_A\) and hence the system is not a capacitor. However, we observe that
\(C_1 = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0 b^2}{b - a} = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0 ab}{b - a} + 4\pi\epsilon_0 b = C_{AB} + C_B\)
This system is equivalent to a spherical capacitor (of inner radius \(a\) and outer radius \(b\) and a spherical conductor of radius \(b\) connected in parallel. This is because the charge \(q\) given to the outer shell distributes in such a way that \(\left(\dfrac{a}{b}ight)q\) remains on its inner side while the remaining \(q\left[1 - \left(\dfrac{a}{b}ight)ight]\) lies on its outer side. Hence,
\(\left|\dfrac{q_{in}}{q_{out}}ight|_B = \dfrac{\dfrac{a}{b}q}{q - \left(\dfrac{a}{b}ight)q} = \dfrac{a}{b - a}\)
and the system becomes equivalent to two capacitors in parallel having a common potential \(V\).
(c) To find the capacitance in this situation, let us consider a point P at a distance r from centre of A on the line joining the centres of two spheres. If E be the net field at this point P, then
\(E = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^2} + \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 (d - r)^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dV}{dr} = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left[\dfrac{1}{r^2} + \dfrac{1}{(d - r)^2}ight]\) [as \(E = \dfrac{dV}{dr}\)]
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_{V_A}^{V_B}dV = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \displaystyle\int_a^b \left[\dfrac{1}{r^2} + \dfrac{1}{(d - r)^2}ight]dr\)
\(\Rightarrow V_A - V_B = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left[-\dfrac{1}{r} + \dfrac{1}{(d - r)}ight]_a^b\)
\(\Rightarrow V_A - V_B = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left[\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b} - \dfrac{1}{(d - a)} - \dfrac{1}{(d - b)}ight]\)
For \(d \gg a\) and \(d \gg b\), we get
\(\Rightarrow V_A - V_B = V = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left[\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b} - \dfrac{2}{d}ight]\)

DIAGRAM[3,300]

Since \(C = \dfrac{q}{|\Delta V|}\)
\(\Rightarrow C_2 = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0}{\left(\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b} - \dfrac{2}{d}ight)} \quad ...(3)\)
Using Concept of Self Energy and Interaction Energy
The self energy of a spherical conductor is
\(U_s = \dfrac{1}{2}qV = \dfrac{1}{2}\left[\dfrac{q^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}ight]\) [as \(V = \dfrac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}\)]
while interaction energy of two point charges separated by a distance \(r\)
\(U_i = qV = \dfrac{q_1 q_2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r}\)
So total potential energy of the system is
\(U =  egin{bmatrix}Self \ Energy \ of A\end{bmatrix} +  egin{bmatrix}Self \ Energy \ of B\end{bmatrix} +  egin{bmatrix}Interaction \ Energy \ of AB\end{bmatrix}\)
\(\Rightarrow U = U_A + U_B + U_{AB}\)
\(\Rightarrow U = \dfrac{q^2}{8\pi\epsilon_0 a} + \dfrac{(-q)^2}{8\pi\epsilon_0 b} + \dfrac{q(-q)}{4\pi\epsilon_0 d}\)
\(\Rightarrow U = \dfrac{1}{2} \cdot \dfrac{q^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\left(\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b} - \dfrac{2}{d}ight)\)
Since, we have \(U = \dfrac{(q^2)}{2C}\)
\(\Rightarrow C_2 = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0}{\left(\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b} - \dfrac{2}{d}ight)}\)
This result is identical to the result obtained earlier, using the method of electric field.
Now, if \(d 	o \infty\) then
\(C_2' = \dfrac{4\pi\epsilon_0}{\left(\dfrac{1}{a} + \dfrac{1}{b}ight)}\)
\(\Rightarrow C_2' < C_2\)
Also, \(\dfrac{1}{C_2'} = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 a} + \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0 b} = \dfrac{1}{C_A} + \dfrac{1}{C_B}\)
and hence the given system becomes equivalent to two capacitors \(C_A (= 4\pi\epsilon_0 a)\) and \(C_B (= 4\pi\epsilon_0 b)\) in series.
Also, we observe that in this ILLUSTRATION, (a) and (c) represent capacitors (as here the two conductors have equal and opposite charges) while arrangement given in (b) is not a capacitor (because \(q_B\) is not equal to \(-q_A\)).
questions.hint: (a) Consider the potential of the outer shell to be zero and calculate the induced charge. Then, calculate the potential difference between the shells and use \(C = q/V\).\n(b) Similar to (a), but this time the inner shell is earthed.\n(c) Calculate the electric field at a point between the spheres and integrate to find the potential difference. Alternatively, calculate the self-energies and interaction energy of the system and use the relation \(U = q^2 / 2C\).
methodOfSolving: (a) Use the concept of earthing and potential due to spherical shells.
(b) Apply the same principles as in (a) with the inner shell earthed.
(c) Calculate the net electric field and integrate to find the potential difference, or use the energy method by calculating self and interaction energies.

questions.title: Parallel Plate Capacitor with Spring
questions.questionText:
A parallel plate capacitor with air as a dielectric is arranged horizontally, such that its one plate is fixed and the other plate is connected with a perpendicular spring. 
DIAGRAM[1,100]
The area of each plate is \(A\). In the steady position, the separation between the plates is \(d_0\). When the capacitor is connected with an electric source with the voltage \(V\), a new equilibrium appears, such that the new separation between the plates becomes \(d_1\). Assuming mass of the upper plate to be \(m\), find the
(a) spring constant \(K\).
(b) maximum voltage for a given \(K\) in which an equilibrium is possible.
(c) angular frequency of the oscillating system around the equilibrium value \(d_1\) (amplitude of the oscillation \(<< d_1\)).
questions.solution:
(a) Let the initial extension in the spring, in equilibrium situation be \(x_0\). Then, for equilibrium of lower plate 2, we must have \(Kx_0\) (acting upwards) balancing \(mg\) (acting downwards).
\(Kx_0 = mg\)
When the voltage source is connected, then the plate separation changes from \(d_0\) to \(d_1\) as a result of which the extension of the spring becomes \((d_0 - d_1) + x_0\) so that net extension in the spring becomes \(x_0 + (d_0 - d_1)\).
When equilibrium is attained again, we have
\(K[x_0 + (d_0 - d_1)] = mg + \dfrac{1}{2} \epsilon_0 E^2 A\)
Since, \(Kx_0 = mg\)
\(K(d_0 - d_1) = \dfrac{1}{2} \epsilon_0 \left(\dfrac{V}{d_1}ight)^2 A \quad ...(1)\)
\(\Rightarrow K = \dfrac{\epsilon_0 A V^2}{2d_1^2(d_0 - d_1)}\)
(b) From equation (1), we have
\(V^2 = \dfrac{2Kd_1^2(d_0 - d_1)}{\epsilon_0 A} = \dfrac{2K}{\epsilon_0 A}(d_0 d_1^2 - d_1^3) \quad ...(2)\)
Differentiating w.r.t. \(d_1\), we get
\(2V\left(\dfrac{dV}{dd_1}ight) = \dfrac{2K}{A \epsilon_0} (2d_0 d_1 - 3d_1^2)\)
For \(V\) to be maximum, we have \(\left(\dfrac{dV}{dd_1}ight) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow 2d_0 d_1 - 3d_1^2 = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow d_1 = \dfrac{2}{3}d_0\)
Substituting \(d_1 = \dfrac{2d_0}{3}\) in (2), we get
\(V_{max}^2 = \dfrac{2K}{\epsilon_0 A} \left(\dfrac{2}{3}d_0ight)^2 \left(d_0 - \dfrac{2}{3}d_0ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow V_{max} = \dfrac{2d_0}{3} \sqrt{\dfrac{2Kd_0}{3A\epsilon_0}} \quad ...(3)\)
(c) Let a small displacement \(x\) be given to the upper plate in the downward direction from the equilibrium position. Then the net force on the plate is
\(F = -K[x_0 + (d_0 - d_1) + x] + mg + \dfrac{1}{2}\epsilon_0 A \left[\dfrac{V^2}{(d_1 - x)^2}ight]\)
\(\{ ecause E = \dfrac{V}{d_1 - x}\}\)
\(\Rightarrow F = -K(d_0 - d_1) - Kx + \dfrac{1}{2} \epsilon_0 A \dfrac{V^2}{d_1^2} \left(1 - \dfrac{x}{d_1}ight)^{-2}\)
\(\Rightarrow F = -Kx \left(\dfrac{3d_1 - 2d_0}{d_1}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow m\ddot{x} = -Kx \left(\dfrac{3d_1 - 2d_0}{d_1}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \ddot{x} + \dfrac{K}{m} \left(\dfrac{3d_1 - 2d_0}{d_1}ight)x = 0\)
Compare with the standard equation of SHM, \(\ddot{x} + \omega^2 x = 0\), we get
\(\omega = \sqrt{\dfrac{K}{m}\left(\dfrac{3d_1 - 2d_0}{d_1}ight)}\)
questions.hint: (a)  Balance the forces acting on the upper plate in both equilibrium positions (without and with voltage applied).  \n(b) Find an expression for V in terms of d1 and maximize it.\n(c)  Consider a small displacement from the equilibrium position and analyze the net force.  The resulting equation should resemble the equation of SHM.
methodOfSolving: (a) Apply equilibrium conditions to the plate.
(b) Differentiate the expression for V^2 with respect to d1 and set it to zero to find the maximum voltage.
(c) Write the force equation for a small displacement from equilibrium and compare it with the standard equation of SHM.

questions.title: Parallel Plate Capacitors Connected by a Spring
questions.questionText: Two parallel plate capacitors with area \(A\) are connected through a conducting spring of natural length \(l\) in series as shown. Plates P and S have fixed positions at separation \(d\). Now the plates are connected by a battery of emf \(E\) as shown. If the extension in the spring in equilibrium is equal to the separation between the plates, find the spring constant \(k\).\n\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let charge on capacitors be \(q\) and separation between plates P and Q and R and S be \(x\) at any time.
Distance between plates P and Q and R and S is same because the force acting on them is same.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Capacitance of capacitor PQ is given by
\(C_1 = \dfrac{\epsilon_0 A}{x}\)
Capacitance of capacitor RS is given by
\(C_2 = \dfrac{\epsilon_0 A}{x}\)
From Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL), we have
\(\dfrac{q}{C_1} + \dfrac{q}{C_2} = E\)
\(\Rightarrow q = \dfrac{2x}{\epsilon_0 A E}\)
At this moment extension in spring, \(y = d - 2x - l\) and force on plate Q towards P is given by
\(F_1 = \dfrac{q^2}{2A\epsilon_0} = \dfrac{\epsilon_0^2 A^2 E^2}{8Ax^2 \epsilon_0} = \dfrac{A\epsilon_0 E^2}{8x^2} \quad ...(1)\)
Spring force on plate Q due to extension in spring is given by
\(F_2 = ky\)
At equilibrium,
Separation between the plates = Extension in the spring
Thus \(x = y = d - 2x - l\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \dfrac{d - l}{3} \quad ...(2)\)
\(\Rightarrow F_1 = F_2 = kx = ky \quad ...(3)\)
From equations (1) and (3), we get
\(\dfrac{A\epsilon_0 E^2}{8x^2} = ky = kx\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \left(\dfrac{A\epsilon_0 E^2}{8k}ight)^{\dfrac{1}{3}} \quad ...(4)\)
From equations (2) and (4), we get
\(\left(\dfrac{d - l}{3}ight)^3 = \dfrac{A\epsilon_0 E^2}{8k}\)
\(\Rightarrow k = \dfrac{27\epsilon_0 AE^2}{8(d - l)^3}\)
questions.hint: Use KVL to find the charge on the capacitors. Calculate the electrostatic force on the plates and equate it to the spring force at equilibrium.  Consider the condition that the extension in the spring equals the plate separation.
methodOfSolving: Apply KVL to the circuit to determine the charge on the capacitors.
Calculate the electrostatic force on one of the movable plates.
Determine the force exerted by the spring.
Equate the electrostatic force and spring force at equilibrium.
Use the given condition that plate separation equals spring extension.

questions.title: Equivalent Resistance of a Dodecagon Network
questions.questionText:
A network of 12 resistors each of value \(R = 6 \Omega\) are interconnected as shown in figure, being placed along the sides of a regular dodecagon. Each of the terminals 1, 2, 3, ..., 12 has been connected directly by insulated wires (other than nearest) each of the 9 terminals each of resistance \(R\), there being 9 wires from each terminal making 108 wire connections totally. [Only one set of 9 wires, from terminal 1 have been shown]. 
DIAGRAM[1,200]
Find:
 (a) the equivalent resistance of the network when the current enters at the terminal 1 and leaves at terminal 2.
(b) If the above network were generalised so that there are \(n\) (\(n =\) even) resistors each of resistance \(R\) placed along the sides of a regular \(n\) sided polygon and if each terminal point of a resistor were connected by \((n - 2)\) insulated wires each of resistance \(R\), directly to the \((n - 2)\) terminals, other than its, nearest terminals, find the equivalent resistance across any two terminals of the network (i.e., current entering at one of the two terminals and leaving by the other).
questions.solution:
(a) Since each of the terminals is connected by an insulated wire to each of the remaining 11 terminals by a resistor \(R\), the symmetry shows all the twelve terminals to be symmetrically equivalent before any voltage is applied.
However, asymmetry is introduced just at the point where current enters and also at the point where the current leaves the circuit. All other ten points are symmetry points, all at the same potential. Hence the given network reduces to the following network

DIAGRAM[2,300]

Thus if \(X\) be the equivalent resistance between \(P\) and \(Q\)
\(\dfrac{1}{X} = \dfrac{1}{2R} + \dfrac{1}{2R} + ...	ext{ to 10 terms }+ \dfrac{1}{R}\)
\(\dfrac{1}{X} = \dfrac{10}{2R} + \dfrac{1}{R} = \dfrac{6}{R}\)
Hence \(X = \dfrac{R}{6}\)
The equivalent resistance \(= \dfrac{R}{6} = \dfrac{6}{6} = 1 \Omega\)
(b) Proceeding in the same manner as in (a) we find that the equivalent resistor is given by \(X\) where
\(\dfrac{1}{X} = \dfrac{1}{2R} + \dfrac{1}{2R} + ... 	ext{ to } (n-2) 	ext{ terms } + \dfrac{1}{R}\)
\(\dfrac{1}{X} = \dfrac{n-2}{2R} + \dfrac{1}{R} = \dfrac{n}{2R}\)
Hence equivalent resistance \(= \dfrac{2R}{n}\)
The above symmetry simplification can be done only if \(n\) is even.
questions.hint: Due to symmetry, all points except the entry and exit points are at the same potential.  The network simplifies to a set of parallel resistors between the entry and exit points.
methodOfSolving: (a) Exploit the symmetry of the circuit to simplify it.
(b) Generalize the simplification process for \(n\) resistors.

questions.title: Equivalent Resistance of Infinite Triangles
questions.questionText: A frame made of thin homogeneous wire is shown in figure. Assume that the number of successively embedded equilateral triangle with sides decreasing by half tends to infinity. The side AB has a resistance \(R_0\). Find the equivalent resistance between A and B.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let \(R_0\) be the resistance of the largest triangle.  Then each side has resistance \(R_0/3\). The next embedded triangle will have side length half of the larger triangle. Since resistance is proportional to length, the resistance of each side of the smaller triangle will be \(R_0/6\). Thus, the equivalent resistance of the smaller triangle will be \(R_1 = R_0/6\).
When these two triangles are connected, the equivalent resistance \(R_{eq}\) can be calculated using the formula for parallel resistors:
\(\dfrac{1}{R_{eq}} = \dfrac{1}{R_0/3 + R_1/3} + \dfrac{2}{R_0/3}\)
\(\dfrac{1}{R_{eq}} = \dfrac{1}{\dfrac{R_0}{3} + \dfrac{R_0}{18}} + \dfrac{6}{R_0} = \dfrac{18}{7R_0} + \dfrac{6}{R_0} = \dfrac{60}{7R_0}\)
\(R_{eq} = \dfrac{7}{60}R_0 \approx \dfrac{7}{60}R_0 = \dfrac{7R_0}{60} \approx \dfrac{R_0}{6}\)
If \(n\) such triangles are embedded, then
\(R_n = \dfrac{R_0}{3 	imes 2^n}\)
Now if \(n 	o \infty\), then the equivalent resistance will be \(\dfrac{2}{7}R_0\).
questions.hint: Consider the resistance of each side of the triangles.  How does the resistance change as the triangles get smaller?  Use the parallel resistance formula to find the equivalent resistance.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the resistance of each side of the outer triangle.
Determine the resistance of the next embedded triangle.
Apply the parallel resistance formula repeatedly as more triangles are embedded.
Consider the limit as the number of triangles approaches infinity.

questions.title: Unknown Resistance Measurement with Two Ammeters
questions.questionText: Consider two different ammeters in which the currents are proportional to the respective deflections of the needle. The first ammeter is connected to a resistor of resistance \(R_1\) and the second to a resistor of unknown resistance \(R_x\). Firstly, the ammeters are connected in series between points A and B (as shown in figure). In this case the readings of the ammeters are \(n_1\) and \(n_2\). Then the ammeters are connected in parallel between A and B (as shown in figure) and indicate \(N_1\) and \(N_2\). Determine the unknown resistance \(R_x\) of the second resistor.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\n
questions.solution:
The currents in the ammeters are proportional to deflections produced, let \(\alpha_1\) and \(\alpha_2\) be the proportionality constants.
\(I_1 = \alpha_1 n_1\)
\(I_2 = \alpha_2 n_2\)
The ammeters are in series, hence
\(I_1 = I_2\)
\(\Rightarrow \alpha_1 n_1 = \alpha_2 n_2 \quad ...(1)\)
In the second arrangement the potential drops across resistors are equal as they are in parallel arrangement. Resistances of ammeters have been ignored assuming them to be ideal.
Thus we have \(I_1' R_1 = I_2' R_x\)
Also \(I_1' = \alpha_1 N_1\) and \(I_2' = \alpha_2 N_2\)
\(\Rightarrow R_1 \alpha_1 N_1 = R_x \alpha_2 N_2 \quad ...(2)\)
From equations (1) and (2), eliminating \(\alpha_1\) and \(\alpha_2\), we get
\(R_1 N_1 = R_x N_2\)
\(\Rightarrow R_x = \dfrac{R_1 n_2 N_1}{n_1 N_2}\)
questions.hint: In the series connection, the currents through the ammeters are equal. In the parallel connection, the voltage drops across the resistors are equal.
methodOfSolving: Write the expressions for the currents in terms of the deflections and proportionality constants.
Apply the condition for series connection (equal currents).
Apply the condition for parallel connection (equal voltage drops).
Eliminate the proportionality constants to find Rx.
