questions.title: RC Circuit Analysis
questions.questionText:
In the circuit shown in figure, the battery is an ideal one, with emf \(V\). The capacitor is initially uncharged. The switch S is closed at time \(t = 0\).

DIAGRAM[1,200]
(a) Find the charge \(Q\) on the capacitor at time \(t\).
(b) Find the current in AB at time \(t\). What is its limiting value as \(t 	o \infty\)?
questions.solution:
Let at any time \(t\) charge on capacitor C be \(Q\) and currents are as shown. Since, charge \(Q\) will increase with time \(t\). Therefore,
\(I_1 = \dfrac{dQ}{dt}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]

(a) Applying Kirchhoff's Second Law in Loop MNABM
\(V = (I - I_1)R + IR\)
\(\Rightarrow V = 2IR - I_1 R \quad ...(1)\)
Similarly, applying Kirchhoff's Second Law in Loop MNSTM, we have
\(V = I_1 R + \dfrac{Q}{C} + IR \quad ...(2)\)
Eliminating I from equations (1) and (2), we get
\(V = 3I_1R + \dfrac{2Q}{C}\)
\(\Rightarrow 3I_1R = V - \dfrac{2Q}{C}\)
\(\Rightarrow I_1 = \dfrac{1}{3R}\left(V - \dfrac{2Q}{C}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dQ}{dt} = \dfrac{1}{3R}\left(V - \dfrac{2Q}{C}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dQ}{V - \dfrac{2Q}{C}} = \dfrac{dt}{3R}\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_0^Q \dfrac{dQ}{V - \dfrac{2Q}{C}} = \displaystyle\int_0^t \dfrac{dt}{3R}\)
This equation gives
\(Q = \dfrac{CV}{2}(1 - e^{-2t/3RC})\)
(b) \(I_1 = \dfrac{dQ}{dt} = \dfrac{V}{3R}e^{-2t/3RC}\)
From equation (1), we get
\(I = \dfrac{V + I_1 R}{2R} = \dfrac{V + \dfrac{V}{3}e^{-2t/3RC}}{2R}\)
So, current through AB is given by
\(I_2 = I - I_1 = \dfrac{V + \dfrac{V}{3}e^{-2t/3RC}}{2R} - \dfrac{V}{3R}e^{-2t/3RC}\)
\(I_2 = \dfrac{V}{2R} - \dfrac{V}{6R}e^{-2t/3RC}\)
\(I_2 = \dfrac{V}{2R}\) as \(t 	o \infty\)
questions.hint: Apply Kirchhoff's voltage law to the loops in the circuit.  Relate the current through the capacitor to the rate of change of charge on the capacitor.
methodOfSolving: Apply Kirchhoff's second law to the two loops in the circuit.
Express the current through the capacitor in terms of dQ/dt.
Solve the resulting differential equation to find the charge Q as a function of time.
Differentiate Q(t) to find the current I1(t).
Use Kirchhoff's current law to find I2(t).

questions.title: Charge and Heat Loss in an RC Circuit with Two Capacitors
questions.questionText:
The capacitor \(C_1\) in figure initially carries a charge \(q_0\). When the switches \(S_1\) and \(S_2\) are shut, capacitor \(C_1\) is connected in series to a resistor \(R\) and a second capacitor \(C_2\), which initially does not carry any charge.

DIAGRAM[1,200]
(a) Find the charges deposited on the capacitors and the current through R as a function of time.
(b) What is the heat lost in the resistor after a long time of closing the switch?
questions.solution:
(a) Suppose at a moment \(t\) the charge deposited on \(C_1\) is \(q(t)\). Then,
\(V_{C_1} = \dfrac{q(t)}{C_1}\) and \(V_{C_2} = \dfrac{q_0 - q(t)}{C_2}\)
\(V_R = IR\) where \(I = -\dfrac{dq}{dt}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]
Applying KVL, we get
\(\dfrac{q}{C_1} - (\dfrac{q_0 - q}{C_2}) = IR = -R\dfrac{dq}{dt}\)
\(\Rightarrow R\dfrac{dq}{dt} + \left(\dfrac{1}{C_1} + \dfrac{1}{C_2}ight)q = \dfrac{q_0}{C_2}\)
Put \(\dfrac{1}{C} = \dfrac{1}{C_1} + \dfrac{1}{C_2}\), we get
\(R\dfrac{dq}{dt} + \dfrac{q}{C} = \dfrac{q_0}{C_2}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dq}{dt} + \dfrac{q}{RC} = \dfrac{q_0}{C_2}\dfrac{q}{C}\)
\(\Rightarrow R\dfrac{dq}{dt} = \dfrac{1}{C_2}(\dfrac{C}{C_2}q_0 - q)\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int \dfrac{dq}{\dfrac{q_0 C}{C_2} - q} = \displaystyle\int_0^t \dfrac{dt}{RC}\)
\(\Rightarrow \log_e \left(\dfrac{\dfrac{q - C}{C_2}q_0}{q_0 - \dfrac{C}{C_2}q_0}ight) = -\dfrac{t}{RC}\)
\(\Rightarrow q - \dfrac{C}{C_2}q_0 = q_0 \left(1 - \dfrac{C}{C_2}ight) e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}}\)
\(\Rightarrow q = q(t) = q_0 \left[\left(1 - \dfrac{C}{C_2}ight)e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}} + \dfrac{C}{C_2}ight]\) where \(C = \dfrac{C_1 C_2}{C_1 + C_2}\)
\(\Rightarrow I(t) = -\dfrac{dq}{dt} = \dfrac{q_0}{RC_1}e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}}\)
Charge on \(C_2\), \(q_2 = q_0 - q(t) = q_0 C_1(1 - e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}})\)
So, we observe that the charge on \(q_1\) decays and that on \(q_2\) grows exponentially.
(b) Electrostatic energy at \(t = 0\) is
\(U(0) = \dfrac{q_0^2}{2C_1}\)
Electrostatic energy at \(t 	o \infty\) is final energy given by
\(U_f = U(\infty) = \dfrac{q_0^2}{2(C_1 + C_2)}\)
Since, Heat Loss \(= -\Delta U = U_i - U_f\)
\(\Rightarrow -\Delta U = U(0) - U(\infty) = \dfrac{q_0^2 C_2}{2C_1(C_1 + C_2)}\)
questions.hint: (a) Apply KVL to the circuit and solve the resulting differential equation for q(t).  Remember that current I = -dq/dt.\n(b) Calculate the initial and final electrostatic energy stored in the capacitors. The difference is the heat lost in the resistor.
methodOfSolving: (a) Use KVL and the relationship between current and charge to set up a differential equation. Solve the equation to get q(t) and then differentiate to get I(t).
(b) Calculate initial and final energy stored in the capacitors and find the difference.
questions.answer: (a) \(q(t) = q_0 \left[\left(1 - \dfrac{C}{C_2}\right)e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}} + \dfrac{C}{C_2}\right]\) where \(C = \dfrac{C_1 C_2}{C_1 + C_2}\), \(I(t) = \dfrac{q_0}{RC_1}e^{-\dfrac{t}{RC}}\)\n(b) Heat Loss = \(\dfrac{q_0^2 C_2}{2C_1(C_1 + C_2)}\)

questions.title: Temperature Dependence of a Conductor
questions.questionText: A conductor has a temperature independent resistance \(R\) and a total heat capacity \(C\). At the moment \(t = 0\) it is connected to a dc voltage \(V\). Find the time dependence of the conductor's temperature \(T\) assuming the thermal power dissipated into surrounding space to vary as \(q = k(T - T_0)\) where \(k\) is a constant, \(T_0\) is the environmental temperature (equal to conductor's temperature at the initial moment).
questions.solution:
Here energy is being generated in the resistance at a rate of \(\dfrac{V^2}{R}\). Of which part of energy is being lost in the environment and the rest is utilized in raising the temperature of conductor. So, applying the Law of Conservation of Energy, we get
\( egin{bmatrix} Energy \ supplied \ by the dc \ source per \ unit time\end{bmatrix} =  egin{bmatrix} Energy lost \ in the \ environment \ per \ unit time\end{bmatrix} +  egin{bmatrix} Energy used \ in raising the \ temperature of \ the conductor \ per unit time\end{bmatrix}\)
Hence, \(\dfrac{V^2}{R} = k(T - T_0) + C(\dfrac{dT}{dt})\)
\(\Rightarrow C \left(\dfrac{dT}{dt}ight) = \dfrac{V^2}{R} - k(T - T_0)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{dT}{\dfrac{V^2}{R} - k(T - T_0)} = \dfrac{dt}{C}\)
Integrating the above expression, we get
\(\displaystyle\int_{T_0}^T \dfrac{dT}{\dfrac{V^2}{R} - k(T - T_0)} = \displaystyle\int_0^t \dfrac{dt}{C}\)
Solving this equation, we get
\(T = T_0 + \dfrac{V^2}{kR}\left(1 - e^{-\dfrac{kt}{C}}ight)\)
questions.hint: Use the principle of conservation of energy. The power supplied by the DC source equals the sum of the power dissipated into the environment and the power used to raise the conductor's temperature.
methodOfSolving: Write the energy balance equation.
Formulate the differential equation relating temperature and time.
Integrate the differential equation to find the time dependence of the temperature.

questions.title: Voltage Controlled Switch and RC Circuit
questions.questionText:
The switch in figure closes when \(\Delta V_c > \dfrac{2\Delta V}{3}\) and opens when \(\Delta V_c < \dfrac{\Delta V}{3}\). The voltmeter reads a voltage as plotted in figure. What is the period \(T\) of the waveform in terms of \(R_1, R_2\) and \(C\)?

DIAGRAM[1,250]

DIAGRAM[2,300]
questions.solution:
Start at the point when the voltage has just reached \(\dfrac{2\Delta V}{3}\) and the switch has just closed. The voltage is \(\dfrac{2}{3}\Delta V\) and is decaying towards 0 V with a time constant \(R_2 C\).
\(\Delta V_c(t) = \left[\dfrac{2}{3} \Delta Vight]e^{-\dfrac{t_1}{R_2C}}\)

DIAGRAM[2,250]

Let, \(\Delta V_c (t) = \dfrac{1}{3}\Delta V\), at time \(t_1\), then
\(\dfrac{1}{3}\Delta V = \left[\dfrac{2}{3}\Delta Vight]e^{-\dfrac{t_1}{R_2C}}\)
\(\Rightarrow e^{-\dfrac{t_1}{R_2C}} = \dfrac{1}{2} \Rightarrow t_1 = R_2 C \log_e 2\)
After the switch opens, the voltage is \(\dfrac{1}{3}\Delta V\), increasing toward \(\Delta V\) with time constant \((R_1+R_2)C\), so
\(\Delta V_c(t) = \Delta V - \left[\dfrac{2}{3}\Delta Vight]e^{-\dfrac{t}{(R_1 + R_2)C}}\)
Let \(\Delta V_c(t) = \dfrac{2}{3}\Delta V\), in further time \(t_2\), then
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2}{3}\Delta V = \Delta V - \dfrac{2}{3} \Delta V e^{-\dfrac{t_2}{(R_1 + R_2)C}}\)
\(\Rightarrow e^{-\dfrac{t_2}{(R_1+R_2)C}} = \dfrac{1}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow t_2 = (R_1 + R_2)C \log_e 2\)
\(\Rightarrow T = t_1 + t_2 = (R_1 + 2R_2)C \log_e 2\)
questions.hint: Analyze the charging and discharging cycles of the capacitor.  Determine the time constants for each cycle.
methodOfSolving: Determine the time constant for the discharging phase when the switch is closed.
Calculate the time taken for the voltage to drop from (2/3)ΔV to (1/3)ΔV.
Determine the time constant for the charging phase when the switch is open.
Calculate the time taken for the voltage to rise from (1/3)ΔV to (2/3)ΔV.
Add the two times to find the period T.

questions.title: Resistance of an Infinite Wire Grid
questions.questionText: There is an infinite wire grid with cells in the form of equilateral triangles. The resistance of each wire between neighbouring joint connections is \(R_0\). Fing the net resistance of the whole grid between the points A and B as shown \nDIAGRAM[1,300]
questions.solution:
Since net resistance is to be found between A and B. So let a current \(I\) enter at A and then exit at B.
When \(I\) enters at A then by symmetry a current \(\dfrac{I}{6}\) must flow in the branch AB from A to B.
For current \(I\) to exit from B, a current \(\dfrac{I}{6}\) must flow in the branch AB from A to B. Super-imposing the two, we conclude that a current \(\left(\dfrac{I}{6} + \dfrac{I}{6}ight)\) must flow in the branch AB from A to B.
According to Thevenin's Theorem we have
\(I_{total} R_{eq} = V_{AB} = \left(\dfrac{I}{6} + \dfrac{I}{6}ight)R_0 = \dfrac{IR_0}{3}\)
\(\Rightarrow IR_{eq} = \dfrac{IR_0}{3}\)
\(\Rightarrow R_{eq} = \dfrac{R_0}{3}\)
questions.hint: Use symmetry and superposition principles. Consider the current distribution when current enters at A and exits at B.
methodOfSolving: Apply symmetry to determine the current distribution in the grid.
Use superposition to find the total current flowing through the branch AB.
Apply Thevenin's theorem to calculate the equivalent resistance.

questions.title: Electron Projected in a Magnetic Field
questions.questionText:
A uniform magnetic field \(B\) exists in the annular space enclosed between two cylindrical shells of the inner radius \(a\) and outer radius of \(b\) as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[1,150]
An electron is projected from the surface of inner cylindrical shell perpendicular to it with some initial velocity. The magnetic field is directed along the common axis of the cylindrical shells. Calculate the maximum initial velocity with which this electron should be projected so that it will not hit the inner surface of the outer shell.
questions.solution:
The electron follows a circular path with centre C such that it just escapes the outer shell tangentially and does not collide with it as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,150]
The radius of the circular path followed by electron is given by
\(r = \dfrac{mv}{eB} \quad ...(1)\)
Also, we observe that the length OC is given by
\(b - r = \sqrt{a^2 + r^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow b^2 + r^2 - 2br = a^2 + r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow r = \dfrac{b^2 - a^2}{2b} \quad ...(2)\)
Equating (1) and (2), we get
\(\dfrac{mv}{eB} = \dfrac{b^2 - a^2}{2b}\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \dfrac{eB(b^2 - a^2)}{2mb}\)
questions.hint: The electron will follow a circular path due to the magnetic field.  For the electron to not hit the outer shell, the radius of its circular path must be such that it just grazes the outer shell.
methodOfSolving: Determine the radius of the circular path of the electron in terms of its velocity and the magnetic field.
Relate this radius to the radii of the inner and outer shells.
Solve for the maximum velocity.

questions.title: Motion of a Charged Particle in Crossed Electric and Magnetic Fields
questions.questionText:
A particle of charge \(q\) and mass \(m\) is emitted at rest from the origin with zero initial velocity into a region of uniform electric and magnetic fields. The electric field \(\vec{E} = E_0 \hat{i}\) is acting along x-axis and magnetic field \(\vec{B} = B_0 \hat{j}\) along y-axis.  Find:
(a) the maximum x-coordinate of the particle.
(b) the maximum speed of the particle.
(c) the nature of the path followed by the particle.
questions.solution:
Electric field will provide the particle an acceleration (and therefore a velocity component) in x-direction and the magnetic field will rotate the particle in xz-plane (perpendicular to B). Hence, at any instant of time its velocity (and hence, position) will have only x and z components. Let at time \(t\) its velocity be, 
\(\vec{v} = v_x \hat{i} + v_z \hat{k}\)
Net force on it at this instant is
\(\vec{F} = \vec{F_e} + \vec{F_m} = q\vec{E} + q(\vec{v} 	imes \vec{B})\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{F} = q[E_0 \hat{i} + (v_x \hat{i} + v_z \hat{k}) 	imes (B_0 \hat{j})]\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{F}= q(E_0 - v_z B_0)\hat{i} + qv_x B_0 \hat{k}\)
From Newton's Second Law, we have \(\vec{F} = m\vec{a}\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{a} = \dfrac{\vec{F}}{m} = a_x \hat{i} + a_z \hat{k}\)
where, \(a_x = \dfrac{q}{m}(E_0 - v_z B_0) \quad ...(1)\) and \(a_z = \dfrac{q}{m} v_x B_0 \quad ...(2)\)
Differentiating Equation (1) w.r.t. time, we have,
\(\dfrac{da_x}{dt} = \dfrac{d^2 v_x}{dt^2} = -\dfrac{qB_0}{m} \left(\dfrac{dv_z}{dt}ight)\)
Since, \(\dfrac{dv_z}{dt} = a_z = \dfrac{qB_0}{m}v_x\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{d^2 v_x}{dt^2} = -\left(\dfrac{qB_0}{m}ight)^2 v_x \quad ...(3)\)
Comparing this equation with the differential equation of SHM \(\left[\dfrac{d^2 y}{dt^2} = -\omega^2 yight]\), we get
\(\omega = \dfrac{qB_0}{m}\)
and the general solution of Equation (3) is,
\(v_x = A\sin(\omega t + \phi) \quad ...(4)\)
At time \(t = 0\), \(v_x = 0\), hence, \(\phi = 0\)
Again, \(\dfrac{dv_x}{dt} = A\omega \cos(\omega t) \quad [	ext{as } \phi = 0]\)
From equation (1),
\(a_x = \dfrac{qE_0}{m}\) at \(t = 0\), as \(v_z = 0\) at \(t = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow A\omega = \dfrac{qE_0}{m}\)
\(\Rightarrow A = \dfrac{qE_0}{m\omega}\)
Substituting \(\omega = \dfrac{qB_0}{m}\), we get \(A = \dfrac{qE_0}{m \left[\dfrac{qB_0}{m}ight]} = \dfrac{E_0}{B_0}\)
Therefore, equation (4) becomes,
\(v_x = \dfrac{E_0}{B_0} \sin(\omega t)\) where \(\omega = \dfrac{qB_0}{m} \quad ...(5)\)
Now substituting value of \(v_x\) in equation (2), we get
\(a_z = \dfrac{dv_z}{dt} = \dfrac{qE_0}{m}\sin(\omega t)\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_0^{v_z} dv_z = \dfrac{qE_0}{m} \displaystyle\int_0^t \sin(\omega t) dt\)
\(\Rightarrow v_z = \dfrac{qE_0}{m\omega}(1 - \cos(\omega t))\)
Again substituting \(\omega = \dfrac{qB_0}{m}\), we get
\(v_z = \dfrac{E_0}{B_0} (1 - \cos(\omega t)) \quad ...(6)\)
On integrating equations for \(v_x\) and \(v_z\) from (5) and (6), and knowing that at \(t = 0\), \(x = 0\) and \(z = 0\), we get
\(x = \dfrac{E_0}{B_0 \omega}(1 - \cos\omega t)\) and \(z = \dfrac{E_0}{B_0}(\omega t - \sin\omega t)\)
These equations are the equations for a cycloid which is defined as the path generated by the point on the circumference of a wheel rolling on a ground.

DIAGRAM[1,300]

In the present case, radius of the rolling wheel is \(\dfrac{E_0}{B_0 \omega}\). The maximum displacement along x-direction is \(\dfrac{2E_0}{B_0 \omega}\). The x-displacement becomes zero at \(t = 0, \dfrac{2\pi}{\omega}, \dfrac{4\pi}{\omega}\), etc.
questions.hint: The electric field accelerates the particle along the x-axis, while the magnetic field causes circular motion in the xz-plane.  The resulting motion is a cycloid.
methodOfSolving: Write the expression for the Lorentz force acting on the particle.
Apply Newton's second law to determine the equations of motion.
Solve the differential equations to find the velocity components vx and vz as functions of time.
Integrate the velocity components to find the x and z coordinates as functions of time.
Analyze the equations to determine the nature of the path and the maximum displacement and speed.
questions.answer: (a) Maximum x-coordinate = \(\dfrac{2E_0}{B_0 \omega}\) where \(\omega = \dfrac{qB_0}{m}\)\n(b) Maximum speed = \(\dfrac{2E_0}{B_0}\)\n(c) Cycloidal path

questions.title: Lorentz Force between Moving Charges
questions.questionText: Point charges \(Q_1\) and \(Q_2\) are constrained to move along the x and y-axes, respectively, with the same uniform speed \(v\). At time \(t = 0\), both the charges are at the origin. Calculate the Lorentz force \(F\) acting on \(Q_2\) due to the magnetic field of \(Q_1\) at time \(t\).
questions.solution:
The expression for the magnetic field \(\vec{B}\) at a point P at position vector \(\vec{r}\) from the charge \(Q\) moving with a velocity \(\vec{v}\) is
\(\vec{B} = \dfrac{\mu_0}{4\pi} \dfrac{Q(\vec{v} 	imes \vec{r})}{r^3}\)
Since both charges start from the origin at \(t = 0\), so the position vector of the charge \(Q_1\) is \(\vec{r_1} = \vec{v_1}t\) and the position vector of the charge \(Q_2\) is \(\vec{r_2} = \vec{v_2}t\). The vector displacement \(\vec{r}\) of \(Q_2\) w.r.t. \(Q_1\) is
\(\vec{r_{12}} = (\vec{v_2} - \vec{v_1})t\)
The magnetic field at the position of \(Q_2\) due to the charge \(Q_1\) is
\(\vec{B} = \dfrac{\mu_0}{4\pi} \dfrac{Q_1 (\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{r_{12}})}{r_{12}^3} = \dfrac{\mu_0}{4\pi} \dfrac{Q_1 [\vec{v_1} 	imes (\vec{v_2} - \vec{v_1})t]}{r_{12}^3} = \dfrac{\mu_0}{4\pi} \dfrac{Q_1 (\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{v_2})t}{r^3}\)
The force on a charge \(Q_2\) moving with at velocity \(\vec{v_2}\) in a magnetic field \(\vec{B}\) is
\(\vec{F_{21}} = Q_2 (\vec{v_2} 	imes \vec{B})\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{F_{21}} = \left[\dfrac{\mu_0 Q_2}{4\pi r_{12}^3}ight][\vec{v_2} 	imes [\vec{v_1} 	imes (\vec{v_2} - \vec{v_1})]]\)
Since \(\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{v_1} = 0\), so we get
\(\vec{F_{21}} = \left[\dfrac{\mu_0 Q_2}{4\pi r_{12}^3}ight][\vec{v_2} 	imes (\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{v_2})] \quad ...(1)\)
Taking \(\vec{v_1} = v\hat{i}\) and \(\vec{v_2} = v\hat{j}\), we get
\(\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{v_2} = v^2 \hat{k}\)
\(\vec{v_2} 	imes (\vec{v_1} 	imes \vec{v_2}) = v^3 \hat{i}\) and 
\( |\vec{v_1} - \vec{v_2}| = (\sqrt{2}v)^{3/2}\)
From equation (1), the magnetic force is given by
\(\vec{F_{21}} = \dfrac{\mu_0}{4\pi} \dfrac{Q_1 Q_2}{2\sqrt{2} v^2 t^3}v^3\hat{i}\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{F_{21}} = \dfrac{\mu_0 Q_1 Q_2 v}{8\pi t \sqrt{2}}\hat{i}\), parallel to the x-axis.
questions.hint: First, find the magnetic field produced by Q1 at the position of Q2. Then, use the formula for the Lorentz force on a moving charge in a magnetic field.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the magnetic field B due to Q1 at the position of Q2.
Determine the Lorentz force F on Q2 due to the magnetic field B.

questions.title: Magnetic Field of a Solenoid Wound with a Conducting Strip
questions.questionText:
A thin conducting strip of width \(h\) is tightly wound in the shape of a very long cylindrical coil with cross-sectional radius \(R\) to make a single layer straight solenoid as shown in figure.

DIAGRAM[1,250]
A direct current \(I\) flows through the strip. Find the magnetic induction inside and outside the solenoid as a function of the distance \(r\) from its axis.
questions.solution:
Let us consider one loop, then open it and draw it as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,150]
Since the current is flowing in a strip of width \(h\) so, the current per unit strip width is given by
\(j = \dfrac{I}{h}\)
This current per unit length (also called linear current density) can be resolved in two components \(j_x\) and \(j_y\) as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[3,220]
Outside this type of solenoid, the magnetic field will be due to the component of current along the axis of solenoid as shown in Figure (c).

DIAGRAM[4,160]
For current density \(j_x = j\sin	heta\) along the length of solenoid, by applying Amperes Circuital Law, we get
\(B_{out}(2\pi r) = \mu_0 I_x\)
where \(I_x = j_x (2\pi R)\)
\(\Rightarrow I_x = j\sin	heta (2\pi R)\)
From Figure (a), we have
\(\sin	heta = \dfrac{2\pi R}{h}\)
\(\Rightarrow I_x = j\left(\dfrac{2\pi R}{h}ight)(2\pi R) = jh\)
\(\Rightarrow B_{out} = \dfrac{\mu_0 I_x}{2\pi r} = \dfrac{\mu_0 jh}{2\pi r} = \dfrac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}\)
Inside this type of solenoid, the magnetic field will be due to the component of current perpendicular to the axis of the solenoid. Due to component of current density perpendicular to length of solenoid, we have
\(B = \mu_0 n I_y\), where
\(n = \dfrac{N}{h} = \dfrac{1}{h}\) and \(I_y = (j\cos	heta)h = I\cos	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow B_{inside} = \mu_0 \left(\dfrac{1}{h}ight)(I\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow B_{inside} = \dfrac{\mu_0 I}{h}\sqrt{1 - \left(\dfrac{h}{2\pi R}ight)^2}\)
questions.hint: Consider the current per unit width of the strip. Resolve this current density into components parallel and perpendicular to the solenoid axis. Apply Ampere's law.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the current density j.
Resolve j into components jx and jy.
Apply Ampere's circuital law to find the magnetic field outside the solenoid (using jx).
Apply Ampere's circuital law to find the magnetic field inside the solenoid (using jy).

questions.title: Magnetic Dipole Moment of a Rotating Charged Cone
questions.questionText: A charge \(Q\) is uniformly distributed over the slant surface of a thin walled right circular cone of semi-vertex angle \(\theta\) and height \(h\) as shown in Figure. The cone is uniformly rotated about its axis at angular velocity \(\omega\). Calculate the magnetic dipole moment associated with the cone.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,160]
questions.solution:
\(M = IA = \left(\dfrac{	ext{Charge Circulating}}{	ext{Period of Revolution}}ight)	ext{(Area of loop)}\)
Let us consider a small, current carrying loop element, having thickness \(dx\) at a distance \(x\) from the base of the cone as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]DIAGRAM[3,150]
If \(dM\) is the magnetic moment of this small loop having charge \(dq\), radius \(r\) and rotating with angular velocity \(\omega\) then we have
\(dM = iA = \left[\dfrac{dq}{\left(\dfrac{2\pi}{\omega}ight)}ight]A = \dfrac{\omega}{2\pi}(dq)A\)
where \(A\) is area of the loop or the area circulated by the charge \(dq\) in the loop. Also, we know that
\(dq = \sigma dA\), where \(\sigma = \dfrac{Q}{\pi Rl}\), \(dA = (2\pi r)\dfrac{dx}{\cos	heta}\)
and \(l\) is the slant height of the cone given by \(l = \dfrac{h}{\cos	heta}\)
\(\Rightarrow dM = \left(\dfrac{\omega}{2\pi}ight) \left(\dfrac{Q}{\pi Rl}ight) (2\pi r) \left(\dfrac{dx}{\cos	heta}ight)(\pi r^2) \quad ...(1)\)
Also, from figure we observe that
\(	an	heta = \dfrac{R}{h} = \dfrac{r}{h-x}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = \left(\dfrac{h-x}{h}ight)R\)
So, from (1), we get
\(dM = \left(\dfrac{\omega}{2\pi}ight) \left(\dfrac{Q\cos	heta}{\pi Rh}ight) \left(\dfrac{2\pi r^2 R}{\cos	heta}ight) \left(\dfrac{h-x}{h}ight)^3 dx\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \displaystyle\int dM = \dfrac{\omega QR^2}{h^4} \displaystyle\int_0^h (h-x)^3 dx\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \dfrac{\omega QR^2}{h^4} \left[\dfrac{(h-x)^4}{-4}ight]_0^h\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \dfrac{\omega QR^2}{h^4} \left(0 - \dfrac{h^4}{-4}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \dfrac{1}{4}Q\omega R^2 = \dfrac{1}{4}Q\omega h^2 	an^2	heta\)
Since we know that the Gyromagnetic ratio for such an arrangement is given by
\(\gamma = \dfrac{M}{L} = \dfrac{Q}{2m}\)
where M is to be calculated and \(L = I\omega\). For a thin walled cone, \(I = \dfrac{1}{2}mR^2\). So, we get
\(M = I\omega \dfrac{Q}{2m} = \left(\dfrac{1}{2} mR^2ight) \dfrac{\omega Q}{2m} = \dfrac{1}{4}Q\omega R^2\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \dfrac{1}{4}Q\omega h^2 	an^2	heta\) 
{we could have bypassed the process of integration}
questions.hint: Consider a small loop element of the cone. Find the magnetic moment of this element and integrate to find the total magnetic moment.
methodOfSolving: Express the magnetic moment dM of a small loop element in terms of its charge, radius, and angular velocity.
Relate the charge dq of the loop element to the total charge Q and the area of the cone.
Express the radius r of the loop element in terms of the height h and the semi-vertex angle θ.
Integrate dM over the height of the cone to find the total magnetic moment M.

questions.title: Magnetic Pressure on a Solenoid
questions.questionText: Find the magnetic pressure which the lateral surface of a long straight solenoid with \(n\) turns per unit length experiences when a current \(I\) flows through it.
questions.solution: In case of a long solenoid, the magnetic field is zero outside the solenoid and \(B = \mu_0 nI\) inside the solenoid. So, the magnetic pressure on the surface of solenoid is given by\n\(P_m = \frac{B^2}{2\mu_0} = \frac{1}{2}\mu_0 n^2 I^2\)
questions.hint: The magnetic pressure is given by \(P_m = \frac{B^2}{2\mu_0}\). Recall the expression for the magnetic field inside a long solenoid.
methodOfSolving: Write down the formula for magnetic pressure.
Substitute the expression for the magnetic field inside a solenoid.
Simplify the expression to find the magnetic pressure.

questions.title: Magnetic Field of an Exponential Spiral Wire
questions.questionText: A wire carrying a current \(I\) is bent into the shape of an exponential spiral, \(r = e^{\theta}\) from \(\theta = 0\) to \(\theta = 2\pi\) as shown in figure. To complete a loop, the ends of the spiral are connected by a straight wire along the x-axis. Find the magnitude and direction of \(\vec{B}\) at the origin.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,250]
questions.solution:
Before we start with the problem, we must know and keep in mind that the angle \( eta\) between a radial line and its tangent line at any point on the curve \(r = f(	heta)\) are related to the function as
\(	an eta =  rac{r}{ rac{dr}{d	heta}}\)
From Biot-Savart's Law, we know that there is no contribution from the straight portion of the wire since \(d\vec{l} 	imes \vec{r} = 0\). For the field of the spiral, we have
\(d\vec{B} =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi}  rac{(d\vec{l} 	imes \hat{r})}{r^2}\)

DIAGRAM[2,250]
\(\Rightarrow B =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi} \int_0^{2\pi}  rac{|d\vec{l}|\sin	heta|\hat{r}|}{r^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow B =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \sqrt{2}dr \left[\sin\left( rac{3\pi}{4}ight)ight] rac{1}{r^2}\)
Thus in this case, we have \(r = e^{	heta}\) and so we get \(	an eta = 1\) and \( eta =  rac{\pi}{4}\). Therefore, the angle between \(d\vec{l}\) and \(\hat{r}\) is \((\pi -  eta) =  rac{3\pi}{4}\). Also
\(d\vec{l} =  rac{dr}{\sin\left( rac{\pi}{4}ight)} = \sqrt{2} dr\)
\(\Rightarrow B =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} r^{-2} dr =  rac{-\mu_0 I}{4\pi}(r^{-1})|_0^{2\pi}\)
Substitute \(r = e^{	heta}\), we get
\(B =  rac{-\mu_0 I}{4\pi}(e^{-	heta})|_0^{2\pi} =  rac{-\mu_0 I}{4\pi}(e^{-2\pi} - e^0)\)
\(\Rightarrow B =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi}(1 - e^{-2\pi})\) out of the page.
questions.hint: Use the Biot-Savart law and consider the symmetry of the problem. Note that there is no contribution from the straight wire segment.
methodOfSolving: Write down the Biot-Savart law for the magnetic field due to a current element.
Determine the angle between dl and r.
Express dl in terms of dr.
Integrate the Biot-Savart law over the spiral path.
Determine the direction of the magnetic field using the right-hand rule.
questions.answer: \(\frac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi}(1 - e^{-2\pi})\) out of the page

questions.title: Magnetic Flux through a Rectangle inside a Cylindrical Wire
questions.questionText: A very long, cylindrical wire of radius \(R\) carries a current \(I_0\) uniformly distributed across the cross section of the wire. Calculate the magnetic flux through a rectangle that has one side of length \(L\) running down the centre of the wire and another side of length \(R\), as shown in Figure.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,300]
questions.solution:
Let us find the magnetic field at a distance \(r\) from the centre of the wire and divide the rectangle into narrow infinitesimal strips of width \(dr\). The magnetic flux through each infinitesimal strip will then be integrated to get the total flux.

DIAGRAM[2,300]
From Ampere's Law, the field inside the wire is
\(B = \left( rac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi R^2}ight)r\)
The field \(B\) is normal to the area of the strip \(Ldr\), so angle between \(B\) and \(dA\) is \(0^{\circ}\). Hence,
\(d\phi_B = B.dA = \left( rac{\mu_0 I_0 r}{2\pi R^2}ight)(Ldr)\cos(0^{\circ})\)
\(\phi_B = \int d\phi =  rac{\mu_0 I_0 L}{2\pi R^2} \int_0^R r dr\)
\(\Rightarrow \phi_B =  rac{\mu_0 I_0 L}{4\pi}\)
questions.hint: Use Ampere's law to find the magnetic field inside the wire as a function of the radial distance. Then, integrate the magnetic flux over the area of the rectangle.
methodOfSolving: Apply Ampere's law to find the magnetic field B(r) inside the wire.
Consider an infinitesimal strip of width dr and length L within the rectangle.
Calculate the magnetic flux dΦ through this strip.
Integrate dΦ from r=0 to r=R to find the total magnetic flux.

questions.title: Motion of a Bar on Rails in a Magnetic Field
questions.questionText: A bar of mass \(m\) is pulled horizontally across parallel rails by a massless string that passes over an ideal pulley and is attached to a suspended object of mass \(M\) as shown in Figure. The uniform magnetic field has a magnitude \(B\) and the distance between the rails is \(l\). The rails are connected at one end by a load resistor \(R\). Derive an expression that gives the horizontal speed of the bar as a function of time, assuming that the suspended object is released with the bar at rest at \(t = 0\). Assume no friction between rails and bar. Also find the terminal velocity obtained by the bar.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,300]
questions.solution:
For the suspended mass \(M\), we have
\(Mg - T = Ma \quad ...(1)\)
For the bar connected to the suspended mass \(M\),
\(T - BIl = ma \quad ...(2)\)
where \(I =  rac{\varepsilon}{R} =  rac{Blv}{R} \quad ...(3)\)
\(\Rightarrow Mg - BIl = (M+m)a\)
\(\Rightarrow Mg -  rac{B^2 l^2 v}{R} = (M+m)a\)
\(\Rightarrow a =  rac{dv}{dt} =  rac{Mg}{M+m} -  rac{B^2 l^2}{(R(M+m))}v\)
\(\Rightarrow a =  rac{dv}{dt} = \alpha -  eta v\) where \(\alpha =  rac{Mg}{M+m}\), \( eta =  rac{B^2 l^2}{R(M+m)}\)
\(\Rightarrow  rac{dv}{dt} = \alpha -  eta v\)
\(\Rightarrow \int_0^v  rac{dv}{\alpha -  eta v} = \int_0^t dt\)
\(\Rightarrow - rac{1}{ eta}\log_e{(\alpha -  eta v)}|_0^v = t\)
\(\Rightarrow \log_e{\left( rac{\alpha -  eta v}{\alpha}ight)} = - eta t\)
\(\Rightarrow v =  rac{\alpha}{ eta}(1 - e^{- eta t})\)
\(\Rightarrow v =  rac{MgR}{B^2 l^2} \left[1 - e^{- rac{B^2 l^2 t}{R(M+m)}}ight]\)
At the terminal velocity of the bar, say \(v_T\), we have
\(\Rightarrow Mg -  rac{B^2 l^2 v_T}{R} = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow Mg =  rac{B^2 l^2}{R}v_T\)
\(\Rightarrow v_T =  rac{MgR}{B^2 l^2}\)
questions.hint: Apply Newton's second law to both the bar and the suspended mass. Consider the motional EMF induced in the bar and the resulting current.
methodOfSolving: Write the force balance equations for the hanging mass and the bar.
Express the current in the bar in terms of the induced EMF and the resistance R.
Relate the induced EMF to the velocity of the bar and the magnetic field.
Combine the equations and solve the resulting differential equation for the velocity v(t).
To find the terminal velocity, set the acceleration to zero in the velocity equation.
questions.answer: \(v(t) = \frac{MgR}{B^2 l^2} \left[1 - e^{-\frac{B^2 l^2 t}{R(M+m)}}\right]\)\nTerminal Velocity: \(v_T = \frac{MgR}{B^2 l^2}\)

questions.title: Velocity of a Charge due to Changing Magnetic Field in a Solenoid
questions.questionText: A long solenoid has \(n\) turns per unit length, radius \(R\) and carries a current \(I\) is kept in gravity free region. From its axis, at a distance twice that of its radius, a charge \(+q\) and mass \(m\) is placed. If the current in solenoid is suddenly switched off, find the velocity attained by the charge.
questions.solution:
The magnetic field inside the solenoid is along the axis of the solenoid and is given by
\(B_{inside} = \mu_0 nI\)

DIAGRAM[1,250]
Let the duration in which field drops to zero after switching off the current in the solenoid be \(\Delta t\). Due to the switching off the current to the solenoid, an electric field \(E_{nc}\) is induced at a distance \(x = 2R\) i.e., outside the solenoid in this time interval \(\Delta t\). So, we have
\(E_{nc}(2\pi x) = -A \left( rac{\Delta B}{\Delta t}ight) = -\pi R^2 \left( rac{0 - \mu_0 nI}{\Delta t}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow E_{nc}(2\pi x) = \pi R^2 \left( rac{\mu_0 nI}{\Delta t}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow E_{nc} = R  rac{R}{2x}  rac{\mu_0 nI}{\Delta t} =  rac{R}{2(2R)} rac{\mu_0 nI}{\Delta t} =  rac{R}{4} \left( rac{\mu_0 nI}{\Delta t}ight) \quad ...(1)\)
Due to this induced electric field, the charge \(+q\) experiences an impulse in this duration which is given by
\(F\Delta t = mv - 0\)
\(\Rightarrow (qE_{nc})\Delta t = mv\)
Using equation (1), we get
\(q\left[ rac{R}{4}\left( rac{\mu_0 nI}{\Delta t}ight)ight]\Delta t = mv\)
\(\Rightarrow v =  rac{\mu_0 nIqR}{4m}\)
questions.hint: Use Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction to find the induced electric field. Then, calculate the impulse experienced by the charge due to the induced electric field and relate it to the change in momentum.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the magnetic field inside the solenoid.
Apply Faraday's law to find the induced electric field outside the solenoid when the current is switched off.
Determine the impulse on the charge due to the induced electric field.
Relate the impulse to the change in momentum of the charge to find its final velocity.

questions.title: RL Circuit Analysis
questions.questionText: The switch in Figure is open for \(t < 0\) and then closed at time \(t = 0\). Find the current in the inductor and the current in the switch as functions of time thereafter.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,300]
questions.solution:
For loop abefa, we have
\(-4I - 4(I - I_1) + 10 = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow -4I_1 + 8I = 10 \quad ...(1)\)
For loop bcdeb, we have
\(-8I_1 - (1) rac{dI_1}{dt} + 4(I - I_1) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow -12I_1 + 4I =  rac{dI_1}{dt} \quad ...(2)\)

DIAGRAM[2,300]
Multiplying (2) by 2 and then subtracting from (1), we get
\(-4I_1 + 24I_1 = 10 - 2 rac{dI_1}{dt}\)
\(\Rightarrow 20I_1 = 10 - 2 rac{dI_1}{dt}\)
\(\Rightarrow  rac{dI_1}{dt} = 5 - 10I_1\)
\(\Rightarrow \int_0^{I_1}  rac{dI_1}{5 - 10I_1} = \int_0^t dt\)
\(\Rightarrow - rac{1}{10} \log_e{(5 - 10I_1)}|_0^{I_1} = t\)
\(\Rightarrow \log_e{\left( rac{5 - 10I_1}{5}ight)} = -10t\)
\(\Rightarrow 5 - 10I_1 = 5e^{-10t}\)
\(\Rightarrow I_1 = 0.5(1 - e^{-10t})	ext{ A} \quad 	ext{{current through the inductor}}\)
The current through the switch is \(I\), calculated from either of the equations to be
\(I =  rac{1}{8}(10 + 4I_1)\)
\(\Rightarrow I = 1.25 + 0.5I_1\)
\(\Rightarrow I = 1.25 + (0.5)(0.5)(1 - e^{-10t})\)
\(\Rightarrow I = 1.25 + 0.25 - 0.25e^{-10t}\)
\(\Rightarrow I = (1.5 - 0.25e^{-10t})	ext{ A} \quad 	ext{{current through the switch}}\)
questions.hint: Apply Kirchhoff's voltage law to the two loops in the circuit. Solve the resulting system of differential equations.
methodOfSolving: Write down Kirchhoff's voltage law for the two loops in the circuit.
Solve the resulting system of equations to find the currents I and I1 as functions of time.
questions.answer: Inductor Current: \(I_1 = 0.5(1 - e^{-10t})\text{ A}\)\nSwitch Current: \(I = (1.5 - 0.25e^{-10t})\text{ A}\)

questions.title: Moving Wire in Magnetic Field and RLC Circuit
questions.questionText:
A conducting wire PQ of length \(l = 1	ext{ m}\) is moved in a uniform magnetic field \(B = 4	ext{ T}\) with constant velocity \(v = 2	ext{ ms}^{-1}\) towards right as shown in Figure.  If \(R = 2 \Omega\), \(C = 1 	ext{ F}\) and \(L = 4 	ext{ H}\) then, answer the following questions.

DIAGRAM[1,200]
(a) If \(V_P\) and \(V_Q\) are potentials of the point P and Q respectively, then find \(V_P - V_Q\).
(b) Find the potential difference across the inductor.
(c) What is the potential difference across the capacitor?
(d) Calculate the potential difference across the resistor.
(e) Determine the rate of change of current in the inductor.
(f) Find the current through capacitor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\).
(g) Calculate the current through resistor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\).
(h) What is the current through inductor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\)?
(i) Find the current through wire PQ at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\).
(j) Calculate the force required to move the wire with the given constant velocity of 2 ms⁻¹ at t=2s.
(k) Find the energy supplied per second by the source.
(l) Calculate the total power generated by the applied external force.
(m) What is the magnetic energy stored per second in inductor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\)?
(n) Find the energy dissipated per second in the resistor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\).
(o) Calculate the electrostatic energy stored per second in capacitor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\).
questions.solution:
*(a)* Using Fleming's Right Hand Rule, we see that the induced current in the wire PQ is from Q to P. So, we have
\(V_P - V_Q = \varepsilon = Blv = (4)(1)(2) = 8 	ext{ V}\)
*(b)* Inductor being connected in parallel to the emf source PQ has same potential difference developed across the emf source. So
\(V_L = \varepsilon = Blv = 8 	ext{ V}\)
*(c)* Capacitor being connected in parallel to the emf source PQ has same potential difference developed across the emf source. So
\(V_c = \varepsilon = Blv = 8 	ext{ V}\)
*(d)* Resistor being connected in parallel to the emf source PQ has same potential difference developed across the emf source. So
\(V_R = \varepsilon = Blv = 8 	ext{ V}\)
*(e)* Since \(V_L = 8 	ext{ V}\)
\(\Rightarrow L rac{di}{dt} = 8\)
\(\Rightarrow 4 rac{di}{dt} = 8\)
\(\Rightarrow  rac{di}{dt} = 2 	ext{ As}^{-1}\)
*(f)* Charge on the capacitor is
\(Q = C\varepsilon = (1)(8) = 8 	ext{ coulomb}\)
\(\Rightarrow i_2 =  rac{dQ}{dt} =  rac{d}{dt}(8) = 0\)
*(g)* Current through resistor is
\(i_3 =  rac{\varepsilon}{R} =  rac{8}{2} = 4 	ext{ A}\)
*(h)* Since rate of change of current in inductor is \( rac{di_1}{dt} = 2 	ext{ As}^{-1}\)
So, current in the inductor at \(t = 2	ext{ s}\) is

questions.title: Frequency Interval in Series LCR Circuit
questions.questionText: Prove that in a series LCR circuit, the frequencies at which the current amplitude falls to \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) of the current at resonance are separated by an interval equal to \(\frac{R}{2\pi L}\).
questions.solution:
At resonance, we have
\(f_0 =  rac{1}{2\pi\sqrt{LC}}\)
\(\Rightarrow I_0 =  rac{V_0}{R} \quad 	ext{{as Z = R}}\)
According to the problem, we have \(I =  rac{I_0}{\sqrt{2}}\)

DIAGRAM[1,200]
\(\Rightarrow  rac{1}{\sqrt{2}} rac{V_0}{R} =  rac{V_0}{\sqrt{R^2 + \left(\omega L -  rac{1}{\omega C}ight)^2}}\)
\(\Rightarrow 2R^2 = R^2 + \left(\omega L -  rac{1}{\omega C}ight)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega L -  rac{1}{\omega C} = \pm R\)
If \(f_1\) and \(f_2\) are two corresponding frequencies, then
\(2\pi f_1 L -  rac{1}{2\pi f_1 C} = R \quad ...(1)\)
\(2\pi f_2 L -  rac{1}{2\pi f_2 C} = -R \quad ...(2)\)
Dividing (1) by \(f_2\), (2) by \(f_1\) and solving, we get
\( rac{2\pi f_1 L}{f_2} -  rac{1}{2\pi f_1 f_2 C} =  rac{R}{f_2}\)
\( rac{2\pi f_2 L}{f_1} -  rac{1}{2\pi f_1 f_2 C} =  rac{-R}{f_1}\)
Subtracting the above two equations:
\(2\pi L\left( rac{f_1}{f_2} -  rac{f_2}{f_1}ight) = R\left( rac{1}{f_2} +  rac{1}{f_1}ight)\)
\(2\pi L\left( rac{f_1^2 - f_2^2}{f_1 f_2}ight) = R\left( rac{f_1 + f_2}{f_1 f_2}ight)\)
\(2\pi L(f_1 - f_2)\left( rac{f_1 + f_2}{f_1 f_2}ight) = R\left( rac{f_1 + f_2}{f_1 f_2}ight)\)
\(2\pi L(f_1 - f_2) = R\)
\(f_1 - f_2 =  rac{R}{2\pi L}\)
questions.hint: The current amplitude in a series LCR circuit is given by \(I = \frac{V_0}{\sqrt{R^2 + (\omega L - \frac{1}{\omega C})^2}}\). At resonance, \(\omega_0 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{LC}}\) and \(I_0 = \frac{V_0}{R}\).
methodOfSolving: Write the expression for the current amplitude in a series LCR circuit.
Set the current amplitude to \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\) of the resonant current.
Solve for the frequencies f1 and f2.
Find the difference f1 - f2.

questions.title: Charged Particle in Concentric Spherical Shells
questions.questionText:
Two concentric spherical shells have radii \(R\) and \(2R\). The outer shell is grounded and the inner one is given a charge \(+Q\). A small particle having mass \(m\) and charge \(-q\) enters the outer shell through a small hole in it. The speed of the charge entering the shell was \(u\) and its initial line of motion was at a distance \(a = \sqrt{2}R\) from the centre.

DIAGRAM[1,250]
(a) Find the radius of curvature of the path of the particle immediately after it enters the shell.
(b) Find the speed with which the particle will hit the inner sphere. Assume that distribution of charge on the spheres do not change due to presence of the charge particle.
questions.solution:
Charge \(-Q\) is induced on the inner surface of the outer shell. There is no charge on the outer surface of the shell as it is grounded.
An electric field exists in the space between the two shells.
\(E =  rac{KQ}{R^2}\) for \(R < r < 2R\)
Just after the charge enters, it experience a force due to this electric field directed towards the centre.
\(F =  rac{KQq}{R^2}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]
Component of this force perpendicular to the direction of instantaneous velocity u is
\(F_L = F\sin	heta =  rac{F a}{\sqrt{2}R} =  rac{KQq a}{\sqrt{2}R^3}\)
If radius of curvature of the path is \(r\)
\( rac{mu^2}{r} = F_L\)
\(\implies r =  rac{mu^2}{F_L} =  rac{\sqrt{2}mu^2 R^3}{KQqa}\)
\(\implies r =  rac{16\sqrt{2} \pi \epsilon_0 R^3 mu^2}{Qq a}\)
(b) The potential difference between the two spheres is
\(V_{inner} - V_{outer} =  rac{KQ}{R} -  rac{KQ}{2R} =  rac{KQ}{2R}\)
Energy conservation for the charge entering the shell gives:
\( rac{1}{2}mv^2 + (-q)V_{inner} =  rac{1}{2}mu^2 + (-q)V_{outer}\)
\(\implies  rac{1}{2}mv^2 =  rac{1}{2}mu^2 + q(V_{inner} - V_{outer})\)
\(\implies  rac{1}{2}mv^2 =  rac{1}{2}mu^2 +  rac{Qq}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R}\)
\(\implies v = \sqrt{u^2 +  rac{Qq}{4\pi\epsilon_0 mR}}\)
questions.hint: (a) Consider the force on the charged particle due to the electric field between the shells and use the formula for centripetal force.\n(b) Use the principle of energy conservation.
methodOfSolving: (a) Apply Coulomb's law to find the electric force on the particle. Use the formula for centripetal force to relate this force to the radius of curvature.
(b) Apply the principle of energy conservation to find the speed of the particle when it hits the inner sphere.

questions.title: Force between Charged Sphere and Hemisphere
questions.questionText:
A spherical shell of radius \(R\) carries a uniformly distributed surface charge \(q\). A hemispherical shell of radius \(r < R\) is placed covering it with its centre coinciding with that of the sphere of radius \(R\). The hemisphere has a uniform surface charge \(q/2\) on it. The charge distribution on the sphere and the hemisphere is not affected due to each other.

(b) Now half of the inner sphere is removed along with its charge (i.e., the remaining half has charge \(q/2\)). Find the force between the bigger and smaller hemispheres in the two cases shown in figure (a) and figure (b).

DIAGRAM[2,200]
(c) Explain why the force in part (b) is different in the two cases.
DIAGRAM[3,200]

(a) The sphere can be replaced with a point charge \((q)\) at its centre. We can either calculate the force applied by \(q\) on each ring element of the hemisphere and add it to get the resultant force or we can calculate electric field produced by the hemisphere at its centre (by considering similar ring elements). Let's proceed to the second method.
Recall that field due to a charged ring on its axis is given by
\(E =  rac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}  rac{Qx}{(R^2 + x^2)^{3/2}}\)
Consider a ring element on the hemisphere as shown.

DIAGRAM[4,250]
Charge on the ring \(=  rac{q}{2\pi R^2}(2\pi R)\sin	heta d	heta = Q\cos	heta d	heta\)
\(dE_{ring} =  rac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}  rac{(Q\cos	heta d	heta)R\sin	heta}{(R^2 + R^2 \sin^2	heta)^{3/2}} =  rac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}  rac{\cos	heta \sin	heta d	heta}{(1 + \sin^2	heta)^{3/2}}\)
Put \(r = 1 + \sin^2	heta\)
\(\implies dr = 2\sin	heta \cos	heta d	heta \implies  rac{dr}{2} = \sin	heta \cos	heta d	heta\)
\(\implies E =  rac{Q}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R} \int_1^2  rac{dr}{r^{3/2}} =  rac{Q}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R}\left[-2r^{-1/2}ight]_1^2 =  rac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}\left(1 -  rac{1}{\sqrt{2}}ight)\)
Required force
\(F = Eq =  rac{Qq}{4\pi\epsilon_0 R}\left(1 -  rac{1}{\sqrt{2}}ight)\)
(b) Complete the outer sphere.
Now this sphere will exert no force on the inner hemisphere.
This means the two hemispheres in the outer sphere exert equal and opposite force on the inner hemisphere.
Call the forces on inner sphere due to two halves \(H_1\) and \(H_2\) of outer sphere as \(F_1\) and \(F_2\).
\(F_1 = F_2 = F^{'}\) (say)
Now complete the inner sphere with outer sphere as hemispherical
Now, force between one half of inner sphere (h1) and the outer sphere is very much like that between H1 and inner hemisphere in previous drawing.
Force between \(H_2\) and outer hemisphere is like \(F_2\) in previous drawing.
\(\implies\) Resultant force on inner ball due to outer hemisphere is \(F_1 + F_2 = 2F(-)\)
This force is already known to us from the previous question.
\(\implies\) Force between the outer and the inner hemispheres = half the answer obtained in last question
\(F =  rac{Q}{8\pi\epsilon_0 R^2}\left(1 -  rac{1}{\sqrt{2}}ight)\)

DIAGRAM[5,250]
(c) In case (a), the force is attractive because the charges on the inner and outer hemispheres are opposite.  In case (b),
DIAGRAM[6,250] the force is repulsive because the charges are the same.  The difference comes from the way the charges are arranged and interact. The solution provided does not sufficiently explain why this is the case.

questions.title: Magnetic Field due to a Semicircular Arc
questions.questionText: A current carrying wire is in the shape of a semicircle of radius \(R\) and has current \(I\). \(M\) is midpoint of the arc and point \(P\) lies on extension of MC at a distance \(2R\) from M. Find the magnetic field due to circular arc at point P.\n\nDIAGRAM[1,250]

Point P lies on the circumference of the circle. Consider an element subtending angle \(d	heta\) at the centre of the circle. Field at P due to this element is given by Biot – Savart law.
\(dB =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi}  rac{dl \sin(90^\circ -  rac{	heta}{2})}{l^2}\)
Where \(dl = Rd	heta\) and \(r = 2R\cos\left( rac{	heta}{2}ight)\)

\(dB =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi}  rac{Rd	heta \sin(90^\circ -  rac{	heta}{2})}{[2R\cos( rac{	heta}{2})]^2} = - rac{\mu_0 I}{16\pi R} \sec\left( rac{	heta}{2}ight)d	heta\)

\( =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi R} [2\ln(\sec rac{	heta}{2} + 	an rac{	heta}{2})]_0^{\pi/2}\)
\(=  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi R} [2\ln(\sqrt{2} + 1) - 2\ln(1 + 0)]\)
\( =  rac{\mu_0 I}{4\pi R} 2\ln(\sqrt{2} + 1) =  rac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi R}\ln(\sqrt{2} + 1)\)

\(= 2T\sin\left( rac{\Delta	heta}{2}ight) = T\Delta	heta\)

From microscopic form of Ohm's law we can write
\(\sigma E_1 = \sigma E_2 = I\implies  rac{E_1}{E_2} =  rac{R_1}{R_2}\)

\(2\pi a E_m = \pi a^2  rac{dB}{dt} \implies E_m =  rac{a}{2} rac{dB}{dt}\)
There is accumulation of charge at the junctions which produce additional electric field in the conductor. If \(R_1 > R_2\), then \(E_1 > E_2\). In this case the charge at the upper junction is negative and charge at the lower junction will be positive. In figure \(E_0^{'}\) is electric field due to charge.

(b) Explain how charge accumulation at junctions due to the induced EMF affects the electric field in each semicircular wire.

questions.title: RLC Circuit Analysis with Multiple Switches
questions.questionText:
In the circuit shown in the figure, one of the three switches is kept closed and other two are open. The value of resistance is \(R = 20 \Omega\). When the angular frequency (\(\omega\)) of the 100 V source is adjusted to 500 rad/s, 1000 rad/s and 2000 rad/s it was found that the current \(I\) was 4A, 5A and 4A respectively.

DIAGRAM[1,250]
(a) Which switch is closed? (\(S_1\), \(S_2\) or \(S_3\))
(b) Find the value of \(L\) and \(C\).
questions.solution:
When current is 5A, the impedance is
\(Z =  rac{V}{I} =  rac{100}{5} = 20 \Omega\)
This is equal to R.
Hence for \(\omega = 1000	ext{ rad/s}\)
\(Z = R = 20 \Omega\)
This is possible only if \(S_1\) is closed and
\(\omega_r L =  rac{1}{\omega_r C}\)
\(\implies LC =  rac{1}{\omega_r^2} =  rac{1}{10^6} \quad ...(i)\)
When \(\omega = 500 	ext{ rad/s}\), \(I = 4 	ext{ A}\)
\(Z =  rac{100}{4} = 25 \Omega\)
\(\sqrt{R^2 + X^2} = 25 \implies X = 15 \Omega\)
\( rac{1}{\omega C} - \omega L = 15 \quad ...(ii)\)
[Note that X is not \(\omega L -  rac{1}{\omega C}\), since on increasing the frequency from 500 rad/s to 1000 rad/s the impedance is decreasing]
Solving (i) and (ii) \(L = 10 	ext{ mH}\), \(C = 100 \mu F\)
questions.hint: (a) When the impedance is equal to R, the circuit is in resonance.  Analyze the circuit configurations to determine which switch should be closed for resonance at 1000 rad/s.\n(b) Use the impedance values at different frequencies to set up equations to solve for L and C.
methodOfSolving: (a) Analyze the impedance at ω = 1000 rad/s. Determine which switch configuration results in Z = R.
(b) Write the impedance equations at ω = 500 rad/s and ω = 1000 rad/s. Solve these equations simultaneously to find L and C.

questions.title: Polarization of a Conducting Sphere in an Electric Field
questions.questionText:
A neutral conducting solid sphere of radius R is placed in a uniform external electric field E₀. 

(a) Determine the electric field due to the induced charges inside the sphere.
(b) Find the electric field just outside the surface of the sphere as a function of the angle θ (measured from the direction of the external field).
(c) Calculate the dipole moment of the polarized sphere.
questions.solution:
(a) Inside a conductor, the electric field due to induced charges is equal and opposite to the external electric field. Therefore, the net electric field inside the conductor is zero. Thus, the electric field due to induced charges inside the sphere is -E₀. 

(b)  The electric field just outside the surface of the conductor is twice the external field in the direction perpendicular to the surface.  The electric field just outside the surface of the sphere as a function of θ is given by E = 3E₀cosθ. 

(c) The dipole moment (P) of a polarized sphere is given by P = 4πε₀R³E₀.
questions.hint:
(a) Recall that the electric field inside a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium is zero.
(b) The electric field just outside the conductor is related to the surface charge density, which in turn is related to the external field.
(c) The dipole moment is related to the induced dipole moment and external field.
methodOfSolving: (a) Apply the principle of electrostatic equilibrium inside a conductor.
(b) Use Gauss's law to relate the electric field just outside the sphere to the surface charge density and the external field.
(c) Use the formula for the dipole moment of a sphere in an external electric field.

questions.title: Potential Difference in a Non-Uniform Ring
questions.questionText:
Figure shows a conducting neutral ring of radius \(a\) made from two different wires of uniform cross-section as shown. A magnetic field exists inside the ring which varies with time as \(B = kt\) (k is a constant). Neglect any charge that appears on the surface of the ring. The upper half of the ring has resistance twice as compared to the lower half. 

(a) For a uniform ring (same resistivity throughout), determine the potential difference between points A and B.
(b) For the given non-uniform ring (as in the diagram), find the conservative electric field along the tangent of the circular ring.
(c) For the given non-uniform ring (as in the diagram), calculate the potential difference between points B and A, \(V_{BA}\).
questions.solution:
(a) For a uniform ring, the induced electric field is given by:
\(E_{nc} \cdot 2\pi a = \pi a^2 \frac{d(kt)}{dt} \implies E_{nc} = \frac{ak}{2}\)
The induced electric field is uniform and non-conservative. There is no potential difference across the ring; therefore, \(V_{AB} = 0\).

(b) For the non-uniform ring, let the current density be J. Since the current is the same throughout, and the upper half has twice the resistivity of the lower half, the electric fields will differ. The induced electric field (E<sub>nc</sub>) is still given by \(E_{nc} = \frac{ak}{2}\).
Let R and 2R be the resistance of the lower and upper halves, respectively.  The current is the same throughout the ring, and the resistivity is \(\rho\) in the lower half and \(2\rho\) in the upper half. The current density is given by J = E/\(\rho\). Since the current is constant, the electric field and resistivity are inversely related. Therefore the electric field in the lower half is twice the electric field in the upper half.  The electric field along the tangent is given by \(E_c = \frac{ak}{6}\).

(c) For the given case, the potential difference is given by: 
\(V_{BA} = \int_A^B \vec{E} \cdot d\vec{l} = \frac{ak}{6} \times \pi a = \frac{\pi a^2 k}{6}\)

\nDIAGRAM[2,300]
questions.hint:
(a) For a uniform ring, use Faraday's law to find the induced electric field and then the potential difference. Consider if it's conservative or not. 
(b) For a non-uniform ring, recognize that the current is uniform but the current density and electric field are not. 
(c) Integrate the electric field along the ring to determine the potential difference.
methodOfSolving: (a) Apply Faraday's law to find the induced EMF in the ring. Since the ring is uniform, use this to find the potential difference.
(b) Use Ohm's law and the relationship between current density and electric field to find the electric field in each part of the non-uniform ring.
(c) Integrate the electric field along the path to find the potential difference between points A and B.
